For Schleiermacher, the doctrinal locus is fundamentally anthropology and religious experience.

  • Essence of religion. Religion is neither doctrine nor ethics but the Gefühl, the “feeling of absolute dependence,” a structure of self-consciousness.

  • Christ and the community. Christ is the one in whom God-consciousness is perfect and archetypal; the church is the historical community in which that God-consciousness is communicated and reproduced.

  • Scripture’s status. Scripture is:

  • the historically primary and normative expression of the Christian community’s piety;
  • the most authoritative record of the early church’s God-consciousness, especially as shaped by Christ.

But: - Scripture does not constitute a divine Word that descends; it is a human religious document that rises from Christian self-consciousness. - Its normativity is functional and historical, not ontologically grounded in God’s immediate speech.

  • “Witness” in Schleiermacher. To call Scripture “witness” here means:
  • it testifies to, and springs from, the piety of the first Christians;
  • its authority is mediated through its capacity to awaken and deepen our own God-consciousness;
  • revelation is effectively located in the experience to which Scripture points, not in a divine address in and through the text itself.

Thus Scripture’s relation to revelation is primarily expressive (expression of human religious consciousness), not instrumental in the sense of a living divine speech-act.

Barth’s christological–pneumatological grounding of Scripture-as-witness

Barth’s denial that Scripture “is” revelation operates in a very different framework.

  • Revelation as event in Christ. For Barth, revelation is:
  • the free, sovereign act of God in Jesus Christ, the one Word of God;

  • a concrete history in which God is Subject, Object, and Act of revelation.

  • Threefold form of the Word.

  • Jesus Christ as the eternal and incarnate Word is revelation in the strict sense.
  • Scripture is the prophetic and apostolic witness to this Word.

  • Church proclamation is the derivative witness that echoes Scripture.

  • Scripture’s status. Barth insists:

  • Scripture is a creaturely, historically-conditioned human text;
  • yet it is uniquely commissioned and set apart by God as the canonical witness to Christ.

Therefore: - In itself (as printed words), it is not identical with revelation; - but in the Spirit’s act, God uses this text as the instrument and locale where Christ the Word encounters the church.

  • “Witness” in Barth. To say Scripture is “witness” is:
  • not to relocate revelation into the community’s consciousness;
  • but to say that the Bible, as human speech, is ordained and continually actualized by the Spirit to become God’s own present speech about Christ.

There is, in Barth, a strong ontological asymmetry: revelation is wholly from above; Scripture is subordinated, but genuinely taken up into God’s self-attestation.

This is a theocentric, christological, pneumatological account, not an anthropological one.

Reformed confessional evaluation and clarification

Classic Reformed theology shares with Barth the insistence that revelation is fundamentally God’s sovereign self-disclosure and that Christ is the center of Scripture, while it rejects both Schleiermacher’s subjectivism and Barth’s sharp separation between Scripture and revelation.

From a Reformed standpoint:

  • Against Schleiermacher.
  • Revelation is not grounded in human feeling of dependence or ecclesial piety.
  • Scripture is not merely the church’s religious self-expression but God-breathed (theopneustos).

  • The church’s piety is normed by Scripture because Scripture is first God’s Word to the church, not the other way around.

  • Qualified convergence with Barth.

  • One may affirm with Barth:
    • the primacy of God’s freedom in revelation;
    • the centrality of Christ as the living Word;
    • the inadequacy of treating Scripture as a static object divorced from the Spirit’s present work.

  • But classically Reformed theology also maintains:

    • the identity (not merely occasional coincidence) of Scripture and the Word of God: what Scripture says, God says;
    • the inseparability of the inscripturated Word and the revelatory act, without collapsing the Creator–creature distinction.

  • Key difference in “witness” language.

  • For Schleiermacher, “witness” is fundamentally anthropological: Scripture is the church’s religious testimony, whose authority is confirmed by its power to awaken God-consciousness.
  • For Barth, “witness” is christological and pneumatological: Scripture is the Spirit-commissioned, once-for-all apostolic testimony that God freely makes, and continually uses as, his own speech about Christ.
  • For Reformed orthodoxy, “witness” is properly canonical and instrumental: Scripture is a divinely authored witness whose human authors truly testify, but whose text itself, by virtue of inspiration, is intrinsically God’s reliable, inerrant self-attestation.

Thus the superficially similar formula “Scripture is not revelation but witness” conceals a decisive divergence: Schleiermacher’s formulation dislocates revelation into human consciousness, whereas Barth—though problematic in his own way—grounds witness in God’s triune self-speaking in Christ and the Spirit’s use of the biblical text.

theological_tensions.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/theological_tensions:

The Reformed critique at the end assumes a strict inerrantist and propositional model of revelation but does not address how Reformed theology itself integrates the dynamic, personal, and Christocentric aspects of revelation, leaving an unresolved tension between its critique and its own tradition.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
theological_tensions.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The tension is this: the critique of Schleiermacher and Barth implicitly presupposed a Reformed view of revelation as inerrant and propositional, but it did not show how classic Reformed theology also treats revelation as dynamic, personal, and Christocentric. The result was an apparent opposition between “inerrant propositions” (Reformed) and “personal, Christ-centered encounter” (Barth, Schleiermacher), whereas the Reformed tradition in fact insists on both.

## Doctrinal analysis: the nature of revelation in Reformed theology

Classic Reformed theology treats revelation as **the triune God’s self-disclosure**, not as the mere delivery of information. From within that framework several points are crucial.

- **Triune and personal.**  
  God reveals himself as Father, Son, and Spirit, not as an abstract deity or a set of truths. The subject of revelation is God himself acting:
  
    - The Father sending the Son.  
    - The Son as the incarnate Word, image, and wisdom of God.  
    - The Spirit as the one who inspires Scripture and illumines the heart.

  Revelation is intrinsically relational: in revealing, God simultaneously gives knowledge of himself and brings the knower into covenant relation with him.

- **Christ as the climactic form of revelation.**  
  Reformed confessions are unambiguous that Christ is the centre and fullness of God’s self-disclosure:
  
    - He is the eternal Word made flesh, the “lively image” of the Father.  
    - All previous revelation (law, prophets, types, ordinances) is ordered to, and finds its intelligibility in, Christ.  
    - All present revelation (preaching, sacraments, inward illumination) is the Spirit’s application of Christ.

  So revelation is not fundamentally a book but a person and history: the incarnate, crucified, risen, and returning Christ.

- **Scripture as divinely authored, inerrant, and instrumental.**  
  Reformed theology insists that the prophetic-apostolic Scriptures are:
  
    - The unique, inspired, and fully trustworthy **inscripturation** of God’s self-revelation.  
    - Sufficient and perspicuous for saving knowledge, faith, and obedience.  
    - The normative medium by which God now reveals Christ.

  But Scripture’s role is instrumental and ministerial, not ultimate. It is not a rival to Christ; it is the Spirit-given witness that infallibly identifies, interprets, and mediates Christ to the church. Its propositional truth does not compete with its personal function; truthful propositions are the Spirit’s chosen means to present the living Christ.

- **The Word in its threefold form.**  
  Without adopting Barth’s exact construction, classic Reformed theology distinguishes closely related “forms” of the Word:
  
    - The **essential Word**: the eternal Son, the Logos.  
    - The **inscripturated Word**: the Spirit-breathed writings of prophets and apostles.  
    - The **proclaimed Word**: the preaching of Scripture through the church’s ministry.

  The preached Word has no independent revelatory status; it is revelatory only as it faithfully expounds Scripture. Yet, when thus expounded, God truly speaks in the present, not merely reports past speech.

- **Revelation and covenantal encounter.**  
  Reformed theology locates revelation within the history of the covenant of grace:
  
    - God’s speaking and acting form a unified covenantal economy: promise, command, judgment, blessing.  
    - The content of revelation is not bare data but God’s own covenant address: “I will be your God, and you shall be my people,” focused in Christ as mediator.

  This makes revelation inherently personal and historical without ceasing to be doctrinal and propositional.

## Dynamic and personal aspects: illumination and encounter

- **Illumination by the Spirit.**  
  The Reformed distinguish between the **external** word (objective revelation in Scripture and preaching) and the **internal** work of the Spirit:
  
    - The Spirit renews the mind, enables faith, and inwardly persuades of the truth and divine authority of Scripture.  
    - This is not new revelation, but a new reception of existing revelation.  
    - The encounter is genuinely personal: the believer hears Christ’s voice in the scriptural Word.

- **Christ’s real presence in the means of grace.**  
  In Word and sacrament, Christ is not merely remembered but really (though spiritually) present to faith:
  
    - Preaching is Christ himself addressing his people with law and gospel.  
    - In the Supper, believers feed on Christ by faith through the Spirit.

  The means of grace are therefore dynamic encounters with the living Lord, mediated through divinely given signs and words.

- **Sanctification as ongoing revelatory appropriation.**  
  As believers grow, they do not receive new canonical revelation, but:
  
    - They are led more deeply into the already-given truth in Christ.  
    - The Spirit applies Scripture to fresh situations, bringing out its manifold implications.  
    - The believer’s knowledge is thus historically unfolding while the inscripturated revelation remains fixed.

  This gives room for experiential and contextual richness without collapsing revelation into subjective experience.

## Integrating propositional and personal revelation

From a Reformed standpoint, to call revelation inerrant and propositional is to specify its **form and reliability**, not to deny its **personal and Christocentric character**.

- **Propositions as covenantal speech acts.**  
  When God reveals himself in the Bible, he does not merely state facts; he promises, commands, warns, comforts, and summons. These are propositional in content yet personal in mode and intent.

- **The Logos and linguistic form.**  
  Because the Son is the divine Word, it is fitting that God’s climactic self-disclosure should be both:
  
    - Personal and historical (Jesus of Nazareth), and  
    - Linguistically and propositionally articulated (apostolic testimony to Christ).

  To separate the person from the propositions that interpret him is to sever form from meaning.

- **Guarding against two opposite errors.**  
  Classic Reformed theology can therefore:
  
    - Reject Schleiermacher’s reduction of revelation to the evolving self-consciousness of the community, because it dissolves God’s lordly speech into human religious experience.  
    - Critically appropriate Barth’s Christocentrism and emphasis on God’s initiative, while rejecting his sharp disjunction between revelation and Scripture and his instability regarding natural revelation.

  The Reformed alternative affirms: God sovereignly reveals himself in Christ, and that revelation is normatively and sufficiently given in the Spirit-inspired Scriptures, which, when proclaimed and believed, are the living voice of Christ to his people.

In classic Reformed theology, then, divine revelation is simultaneously inerrant and propositional in its inscripturated form and dynamic, personal, and Christocentric in its content and mode of encounter.

theological_tensions.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/theological_tensions:

By equating rejection of inerrancy with rejection of Scripture as "objective revelation," the essay collapses important distinctions between different doctrines of Scripture and revelation, and does not consider non-inerrantist yet high views of Scripture.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
theological_tensions.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The weakness is that the essay implicitly treated “inerrancy” and “Scripture as objective revelation” as if they were identical, so that once Schleiermacher and Barth reject inerrancy, they are thereby said to reject Scripture as objective revelation. This conflates distinct doctrinal questions and ignores the possibility of robust, non-inerrantist accounts of Scripture as a real, authoritative vehicle of divine self-disclosure. From a classic Reformed standpoint, this needs clarification and correction.

## Doctrinal distinctions: revelation and Scripture

From a confessional Reformed perspective, at least three distinctions are necessary:

- **Revelation vs. inscription.** God’s self-disclosure (revelation) is a divine act; Scripture is the Spirit-given, creaturely record and instrument of that act. Revelation properly speaking is God speaking; Scripture is God-breathed discourse in creaturely form that both recounts and extends that speaking.

- **Objectivity vs. inerrancy.**  
  - **Objectivity** means that God’s self-disclosure has determinate content, independent of human subjectivity, such that the text addresses us and judges us.  
  - **Inerrancy** (in classic Reformed form) means that Scripture, as originally given, is free from falsehood in all that it affirms, by virtue of its divine authorship.  
  These are related but not identical claims: one could, in principle, affirm that Scripture normatively mediates God’s address while qualifying or denying some form of inerrancy.

- **Modes of authority.** The Reformed confessions ground Scripture’s authority in God’s authorship and Christ’s lordship, not in a particular theory of harmonization or textual precision. Infallibility, sufficiency, and clarity are formal attributes; “inerrancy” is a way of specifying truthfulness under modern conditions of historical and scientific critique.

## Schleiermacher, Barth, and Scripture as objective revelation

### Schleiermacher

Schleiermacher’s view undercuts Scripture as objective revelation more deeply than a mere denial of inerrancy.

- He relocates the primary locus of revelation from God’s sovereign speech and acts to **religious self-consciousness**, especially the feeling of absolute dependence as it flowers in the Christian community.

- Scripture is then:
  - The privileged, normative expression of that communal consciousness.
  - A historical document whose normativity is functional and ecclesial, not ontological and divine.

- Objectivity is thus thinned out:
  - Revelation is not principally God addressing the church through the determinate content of the text.
  - Rather, the text serves as a stimulus and regulative expression of piety.

Even if one imagined Schleiermacher affirming many factual errors in Scripture yet calling it “authoritative,” the deeper issue is that revelation is no longer God’s sovereign Word confronting us in and through the text, but the self-expression of a community’s God-consciousness. This is what conflicts most sharply with a Reformed doctrine of objective revelation.

### Barth

Barth is more complex and stands closer to a high view of Scripture, even though he rejects inerrancy in the classic sense.

- Barth sharply distinguishes:
  - **Revelation** strictly as the triune God’s free self-communication in the event of Jesus Christ.
  - **Scripture** as a human, fallible witness that God sovereignly uses to bear that revelation.

- Yet Barth insists on a strong objectivity:
  - The one objective revelation is Jesus Christ himself, God’s Word in person, not our experience.
  - Scripture objectively witnesses to this once-for-all act and is the ordained sphere where God chooses to speak today.

- The result:
  - Barth can deny that the Bible “is” revelation in a static, ontological sense, while still treating it as the concrete, normative place where the church hears God’s speech.
  - He holds a very high, though dialectical, view of Scripture’s revelatory role without embracing a strict inerrantist formulation.

From a Reformed standpoint, Barth’s reluctance to identify Scripture itself as God’s Word (beyond the “becomes Word of God” language) and his willingness to ascribe actual error to the text are serious departures. But it is inaccurate to say that he therefore lacks an account of Scripture as an objective medium of revelation; his objectivity is Christocentric and event-focused rather than text-ontologized in the Reformed way.

## Classic Reformed stance and non-inerrantist “high views”

The Westminster and Three Forms of Unity present a tightly integrated package:

- Scripture is **the Word of God written**, not merely a human witness that sometimes becomes God’s Word.
- Because God cannot lie, Scripture is:
  - **Infallible** in accomplishing its ends.
  - **True** and **trustworthy** in all that it asserts, grounded in divine authorship.
- This objectivity is not reducible to a theory of errorlessness, but such a theory is a natural implication: what God says, in its proper sense and scope, cannot be false.

At the same time, recognizing the distinctiveness of these claims allows one to see:

- It is logically possible to have a **non-inerrantist yet high view**:
  - Scripture as the unique, divinely commissioned witness to Christ.
  - Scripture as norming norm in the church.
  - Scripture as the primary means by which the Spirit speaks.
- Many post-Barthian and other traditions take precisely this path. From a confessional Reformed standpoint, these positions are defective, but they do not amount simply to “subjectivism” or a complete loss of objectivity.

Thus the correct critique of Schleiermacher and Barth is not merely that they reject inerrancy, but that Schleiermacher relocates revelation into religious consciousness and that Barth’s dialectical account fails to identify the canonical text itself, in a stable way, as God’s enduring, verbally given self-revelation.

In sum, the primary Reformed concern is to maintain that the triune God objectively and authoritatively reveals himself to the church in and through the canonical Scriptures as his own truthful Word, of which inerrancy is a fitting implication rather than the essence.

In classic Reformed usage (e.g., the Reformed confessions):

- **General revelation** (often also called **natural revelation**) refers to God’s revelation of himself in creation, providence, and the constitution of human beings, especially conscience.
- It is called “general” because of its **scope**: it is addressed to all people, at all times, in all places.
- It is called “natural” because of its **medium**: it comes through the created order and the natural operations of human reason and conscience, not through redemptive history or inspired Scripture.

This revelation:

- Truly and objectively **makes God known** as Creator, wise, powerful, righteous, and good.
- Is **clear and sufficient to render humanity without excuse**, but is **not sufficient for the knowledge of God unto salvation**.
- Is epistemically real but is **suppressed and distorted by sin**; thus it does not, as actually received by fallen humans, yield a true theology of God’s grace.

So in classic Reformed theology, “general revelation” and “natural revelation” are virtually synonymous terms for this one mode of divine self-disclosure.

### Special revelation

By contrast, **special revelation** refers to God’s saving self-disclosure in:

- Redemptive acts and words given first to Israel and then in Christ.
- The inspiration of prophets and apostles.
- Holy Scripture as the Spirit-given, inscripturated Word, which now is the normative form of special revelation.

Special revelation is necessary for any **saving knowledge** of God, of Christ, and of the way of redemption.

### Natural theology

**Natural theology** is not a form of revelation, but a **human theological enterprise**:

- It is the attempt, by the use of natural reason, reflecting on general revelation (or sometimes abstract metaphysical principles), to construct knowledge of God.
- In its classic, moderate form (e.g., in much Reformed scholasticism), natural theology seeks to articulate some truths about God (existence, attributes, moral law) **on the basis of general revelation**, while insisting that these are:
    - Severely limited in scope.
    - Non-salvific.
    - Radically dependent on and corrected by special revelation.

In its more rationalist or Enlightenment form, natural theology can be construed as:

- The construction of a theological system **independent of and norming over** special revelation, which the Reformed tradition rejects.

The Reformed confessional position therefore affirms:

- The reality and importance of **general/natural revelation**.
- A modest, subordinate **natural theology** grounded in that revelation and regulated by Scripture.
- The absolute **necessity and supremacy of special revelation** for the gospel.

## Schleiermacher and Barth in light of these distinctions

### Schleiermacher

- Schleiermacher effectively **relocates “revelation” into religious consciousness**, especially the feeling of absolute dependence.
- He does not deny that the world can occasion religious awareness, but:
    - He **rejects** metaphysical speculation about God based on nature in the sense of classical natural theology.
    - “Nature” or historical events function as **occasions** for the self-unfolding of piety, not as an objective, cognitive disclosure of God in the Reformed sense of general revelation.
- What the Reformed tradition would call “general revelation” (God’s objective self-disclosure in creation under wrath and curse) is not a central or robust category for him; rather, the **structure of consciousness** is.
- Likewise, **special revelation** as concrete divine speech and act in history recedes behind the historical development of Christian God-consciousness.
- Schleiermacher therefore largely **dissolves both general and special revelation into a theology of religious experience**, and thus has little place for a classical, epistemically realist natural theology.

### Barth

- Barth’s famous “Nein” to Brunner is directed not at the existence of any revelation in creation as such, but at **natural theology as an independent or preparatory knowledge of God**.
- Barth is deeply suspicious of **natural theology** in both its rationalist and confessional forms, because he believes:
    - It invariably becomes an autonomous human project.
    - It threatens the exclusivity and freedom of God’s self-revelation in Christ.
- On **general/natural revelation**, Barth:
    - Tends to deny that there is an **independent, theologically usable sphere** of revelation in nature that can be conceptually grasped apart from Christ.
    - Reinterprets creation as a reality that is known properly only **in the light of the revelation of God in Jesus Christ**.
- Thus, while the Reformed tradition distinguishes clearly between general and special revelation and then regulates natural theology by Scripture, Barth tends to **collapse all genuine revelation into the event of God’s self-speaking in Christ** and treats talk of “general revelation” as theologically dangerous if it is detached from this Christological center.

## Evaluation from a Reformed confessional standpoint

From a classic Reformed perspective:

- Schleiermacher’s **subjectivizing** of revelation undermines both:
    - The objectivity of God’s general revelation in creation and conscience.
    - The objective, authoritative character of special revelation in Scripture and redemptive history.
- Barth’s emphasis on Christ’s unique self-revelation rightly **guards the primacy of special revelation**, but his polemic against natural theology tends to:
    - Obscure or undercut the confessional affirmation of **general/natural revelation** as rendering all people without excuse.
    - Risk denying that creation itself, as creation, objectively reveals God.

A Reformed account must therefore maintain:

- A real, condemning, non-saving **general/natural revelation** in creation and conscience.
- A limited, derivative **natural theology** that is both possible and perilous, always to be critiqued and normed by Scripture.
- The absolute **necessity and supremacy of special revelation**, climaxing in Christ and inscripturated in Scripture, for any saving and fully true knowledge of God.

In sum, the terms “general/natural revelation” and “natural theology” name distinct realities—divine self-disclosure and human theological construction—which Schleiermacher largely collapses into religious experience and Barth tends to collapse into Christological revelation, whereas Reformed theology carefully distinguishes and orders them under the primacy of special revelation.

## Restatement of the issue

The problem is that I described Schleiermacher’s account of Christ communicating a “perfect God-consciousness” to the church as a form of “supernatural revelation” without specifying whether this is Schleiermacher’s own category or a Reformed one. That blurs two very different conceptual frameworks: Schleiermacher’s post‑Kantian, experiential account of redemption and a Reformed, ontological–covenantal doctrine of special revelation.

## Schleiermacher’s own categories

Schleiermacher does not work with the classic Reformed contrast “natural vs. special (supernatural) revelation” as ontologically distinct divine acts. His basic moves are:

- **Religion as Gefühl.** Religion is neither metaphysics nor ethics, but the immediate “feeling of absolute dependence.” Revelation is not primarily propositional disclosure but the emergence and clarification of this God‑consciousness.

- **Christ as archetype of God‑consciousness.** Jesus is the one in whom God‑consciousness is absolutely dominant and undisturbed by sin. Redemption consists in this God‑consciousness being “communicated” to the community.

- **Historical‑communicative, not ontologically supernatural.** What occurs in Christ and the church is not conceived as a categorical intrusion of transcendent speech-acts into history, but as a unique historical–religious fact that awakens, shapes, and normatively determines piety.

He may speak of “revelation” and allow talk of miracles, but these are consistently subordinated to, and evaluated by, their capacity to enhance and express God‑consciousness. He does not ground them in a distinct order of supernatural divine self‑speech parallel to nature.

So to call Christ’s communication of God‑consciousness “supernatural revelation” is already to translate Schleiermacher into a foreign dogmatic idiom. His own framework is experiential–historical, not a two‑order nature/grace model.

## Reformed categories of natural and special revelation

By contrast, classic Reformed theology distinguishes:

- **Natural revelation.** God’s clear self‑disclosure in creation and providence (Ps 19; Rom 1), truly cognitive, objective, and authoritative, but non‑saving because of human sin.

- **Special (supernatural) revelation.** God’s redemptive self‑revelation in history and Word, culminating in Christ, given by extraordinary divine acts and inspired speech, not derivable from creaturely experience or reflection.

Special revelation in this sense is:

- An objective divine initiative, not an emergent structure of religious experience.
- Intrinsically verbal and doctrinal (God speaks, covenants, promises, commands).
- Authoritative and inerrant as inscripturated Word.

Within this framework, “supernatural revelation” is not a flexible evaluative label (“especially intense piety”), but a specific ontological and epistemic category.

## Correcting the conflation

From a Reformed standpoint, describing Schleiermacher’s redemptive schema as “supernatural revelation” is misleading in two ways.

First, it suggests that he affirms a robust category of special revelation comparable to the Reformed view. He does not. What Reformed theology calls special revelation he recasts as:

- The historically mediated expression of Christian God‑consciousness.
- Normative because of its origin in Christ and the founding community, but not qualitatively distinct as divinely authored speech in the classic sense.

Second, it obscures the crucial Reformed critique: Schleiermacher internalizes and historicizes what should be understood as God’s external, authoritative self‑speech. For Reformed dogmatics:

- Christ does not merely **communicate God‑consciousness**; he is the eternal Logos incarnate, objectively revealing the Father.
- Justification and reconciliation are not the transmission of a special quality of consciousness, but forensic and ontological divine acts grounded in Christ’s person and work, known through God’s special revelation in Word and Spirit.

A more accurate formulation would be:

- Schleiermacher offers a **redemptive communication of God‑consciousness in and through Christ and the community**, which functions for him as the inner core of what he calls revelation.
- From a Reformed perspective, this is **not** properly “supernatural revelation” but an experiential reinterpretation of revelation, subordinating objective divine self‑speech to the structure and enhancement of religious feeling.

The issue, therefore, is not to locate Schleiermacher’s Christ‑event as a special case within a shared Reformed category of supernatural revelation, but to recognize that he operates with a different grammar of revelation altogether, which Reformed theology must fundamentally revise rather than simply relabel.

## Restatement of the issue

The problematic sentence compresses three distinct claims into one:  
- that Scripture is **inerrant**,  
- that Scripture is **God’s own self-revelation** (as opposed to mere human witness), and  
- that Scripture is specifically the **self-revelation of the Triune God**.  

By saying “Scripture is not the inerrant self-revelation of the Triune God,” the statement leaves it unclear which element Schleiermacher rejects, and in what way. From a Reformed standpoint, these elements must be analytically distinguished and then related.

## Doctrinal analysis from a Reformed standpoint

From a classic Reformed confessional perspective, three affirmations belong together but are not identical.

- **Inerrancy**: Because God is truthful and powerful, when he inspires prophets and apostles by the Spirit, the resulting Scripture is without error in all that it affirms, rightly interpreted in its literary and historical context. Inerrancy is a property of the text as the Spirit-given instrument of revelation.

- **Self-revelation**: Scripture is not merely human religious genius; it is the means by which God himself speaks, interprets his own acts, and discloses his will. The text is not simply a record of human God-consciousness; it is God’s own authorized, Spirit-breathed interpretation of his redemptive economy.

- **Trinitarian character of revelation**: In classic Reformed dogmatics, revelation is from the Father, through the Son, in the Holy Spirit. Thus Scripture is the Spirit-inspired apostolic and prophetic witness to the Son, given from the Father. The doctrine of Scripture is inseparable from the doctrine of the Trinity, but not reducible to it.

### Schleiermacher in relation to these three

Schleiermacher does not simply deny “all three” in one move; rather, he reconfigures each.

- Regarding **inerrancy**:  
  - He treats Scripture as the historically-conditioned, fallible expression of the piety of the early Christian community.  
  - He allows for errors of fact, historical limitation, and development; normativity resides not in textual infallibility but in the exemplary intensity and purity of the community’s God-consciousness.

- Regarding **self-revelation**:  
  - Revelation, for Schleiermacher, is fundamentally the modification of human self-consciousness (the feeling of absolute dependence), climactically in Christ.  
  - Scripture is a privileged witness to this consciousness, not the direct self-attestation of God; revelation is primarily an event in religious subjectivity, not an act of divine discourse in and through the text.

- Regarding **trinitarian revelation**:  
  - His dogmatics is formally Trinitarian, but the Trinity functions as a regulative summary of Christian experience rather than as the ontological tri-personal subject who speaks in Scripture.  
  - The Father, Son, and Spirit name the structure of Christian God-consciousness more than the living triune speaker whose voice addresses the church through the written Word.

### Clarified Reformed counter-position

A more precise Reformed formulation, over against Schleiermacher, would run as follows:

- Scripture is the **Spirit-breathed, inerrant Word of God**, such that its propositions, narratives, and commands carry divine authority and are truthful in what they assert.
- In and through this written Word, **the Triune God himself** – not merely the church’s piety – **self-reveals**, interpreting his own being and works, supremely the person and work of Christ.
- Human religious experience, including the church’s piety, is the *fruit* of this self-revelation, not its constitutive locus or norm.

Thus, with analytic clarity: Schleiermacher denies inerrancy as a property of the text, relocates “self-revelation” into the sphere of human consciousness, and functionally de-centers the Trinity as the living subject of Scripture’s speech, whereas Reformed theology insists that the triune God himself inerrantly self-reveals in and by the written Word.

terminology_problems.answer_markdown:
The issue is that the essay speaks of Barth’s “Christ-event” as though “event” were self-evident, but never explains what “event” means in Barth’s dogmatics, nor how this differs both from a mere historical occurrence and from a classic Reformed understanding of the once-for-all work of Christ attested in Scripture. That omission risks suggesting a nebulous, almost free-floating “event” that is detached from concrete history and from the stable content of special revelation.

## Clarifying “event” in Barth’s theology

In Barth, “event” (Ereignis) is not simply a point on a historical timeline. It is a theological category:

- **First**, “event” names God’s free, personal act here and now. Revelation is not a static deposit of propositions; it is God’s living self-giving. God reveals himself only as he acts, and this acting is understood as an ever-fresh event of encounter.

- **Second**, “event” functions christologically. For Barth, Jesus Christ is himself the revelation of God; the incarnation, cross, and resurrection are not simply past facts but the decisive divine act in which God is both Subject and Object of revelation. Speaking of the “Christ-event” signals that revelation is identical with this person and history, not with ideas behind or beyond him.

- **Third**, “event” is also used for the present appropriation of revelation. The Word of God “happens” as an event when God the Spirit makes the biblical witness and church proclamation actually become his speech to us. Scripture as such is not revelation in se; it is the place where revelation may occur as an event, namely, when God chooses to speak through it.

Thus “event” in Barth marks:
- the freedom and immediacy of God’s self-revelation,
- the identity of revelation with the history and person of Christ,
- the present, pneumatic actualization of that revelation in the church’s hearing.

## Reformed evaluation and clarification

From a classic Reformed standpoint, several clarifications are needed.

- **Objectivity and once-for-allness.** Reformed theology insists that Christ’s incarnation, obedience, death, and resurrection are once-for-all historical acts with enduring covenantal significance; they are “events” in the ordinary sense, completed in history and now fixed in their saving meaning.

- **Stability of special revelation.** Those events are authoritatively interpreted and inscripturated in the prophetic and apostolic writings. Scripture does not merely become revelation; it is, as God-breathed, the abiding form of God’s special revelation, though its saving efficacy in individuals is indeed an event of the Spirit’s illumination.

- **Word and Spirit.** The Reformed tradition can acknowledge a certain “event” language: the preached Word is an event of God’s address when joined with the Spirit, and faith itself is an event of regeneration and effectual calling. But these events presuppose a stable, completed work of Christ and a stable, completed canon that do not themselves depend ontologically on being re-actualized to be what they are.

A more precise formulation, from a Reformed angle, would be: Christ’s once-for-all redemptive work is a completed series of historical events whose meaning is definitively given in Scripture, and the Spirit makes that work present and efficacious in the ongoing event of Word and sacrament, without collapsing revelation itself into the moment of encounter.

terminology_problems.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The earlier description of Barth’s “threefold Word of God” was too compressed and potentially misleading. It treated the three forms (Jesus Christ, Scripture, preaching) as if they were straightforwardly and equally “the Word of God,” without indicating Barth’s strict distinction between God’s self-speaking and the human words that only become God’s Word in an event of divine freedom. In addition, it introduced “kerygma” as a label for preaching without explaining what Barth means by it or how it functions in his doctrine of revelation.

## Doctrinal analysis of Barth’s threefold Word

Barth’s starting point is that **God alone is the subject of revelation**. Revelation is not a deposit or object under human control; it is God’s living act of making himself known. Within that framework, Barth speaks of a **threefold form** of the Word of God:

- **First, the revealed Word: Jesus Christ.**  
  For Barth, the one, proper, unsurpassable Word of God is the person and history of Jesus Christ.  
  - Christ is the self-interpretation of God: God’s speech about himself in a human life.  
  - All other “words of God” are such only as they serve and participate in this once‑for‑all event; they are not parallel sources but derivative and instrumental.

- **Second, the written Word: Holy Scripture.**  
  Scripture is the prophetic and apostolic testimony to Jesus Christ.  
  - As such testimony, it is fully human speech, historically and culturally located, exhibiting all the marks of human literature.  
  - Barth famously refuses to identify Scripture in itself, as a set of human texts, with revelation as such. Instead, Scripture “becomes” the Word of God when and as God sovereignly uses these human words as the medium in which Christ is present and addresses the church.  
  - Thus there is a **real distinction** between the **Word of God** and the **human words of the Bible**, yet also an inseparable ordered relation: God has bound his speaking to this canon, and the church expects God to speak here, not elsewhere of its own choosing.

- **Third, the proclaimed Word: preaching (kerygma).**  
  “Kerygma” for Barth is the church’s act of proclamation, especially the sermon, in which Scripture is read and expounded.  
  - Again, in itself this is human speech, fallible and situational.  
  - It may, by the Spirit’s free activity, be taken up and used as a present form of God’s address, so that in and through the minister’s words the living Christ confronts and summons hearers.  
  - Preaching is thus ordered to Scripture, and through Scripture to Christ; it is never an independent locus of revelation.

Across all three forms, Barth insists on **divine freedom and event-character**: Word of God is not an ontic property fused with the text or with ecclesial utterance; it is God’s ongoing act of self-communication in and through these creaturely media.

## Reformational evaluation and clarification

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, there is both continuity and divergence.

- Reformed theology affirms, with Barth, that:
  - Christ is the final and central revelation of God.  
  - Scripture and preaching are genuinely human words.  
  - The Spirit must sovereignly illumine and apply the Word for it to be savingly known.

- However, Reformed confessions typically speak more **ontically and stably** of Scripture as the Word of God:
  - The canonical text, as inspired by the Spirit, is not merely capable of becoming God’s Word in an event, but is *as such* the written Word of God, the norma normans of all proclamation.  
  - Preaching is the Word of God only insofar as it faithfully expounds Scripture; it does not stand on the same conceptual plane as Scripture or Christ.

A clearer formulation, therefore, would be:  
Barth’s doctrine of the threefold Word recognizes Jesus Christ as the one proper Word of God, and views Scripture and preaching as fallible human testimonies that, by God’s free act, can become the effective medium of Christ’s self-revelation; classic Reformed theology appropriates his christocentric emphasis while insisting that the inspired Scripture is, in itself and enduringly, the written Word of God that norms all kerygma.

terminology_problems.answer_markdown:
The criticism is that my essay spoke of “objective revelation” without defining the term, so it was unclear whether I meant revelation as propositional truth, as something ontologically “out there” in God himself, or simply as revelation that is not reducible to human religious consciousness; that ambiguity blurs any evaluation of Schleiermacher and Barth.

## Clarifying “objective revelation” in Reformed terms

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, “objective revelation” has at least three tightly related dimensions, which need to be distinguished but not separated.

- **Ontological objectivity.** God is who he is in himself, the triune Lord, independently of the knowing subject. Revelation presupposes this: it is God’s self-disclosure as the one who already, antecedently, is.
  
  - God’s being, attributes, and decree are not constituted by, or correlative to, human consciousness.
  - When God reveals himself, he does not become something he was not; he makes known what he is eternally.

- **Propositional and cognitive content.** In Reformed theology, revelation includes not only God’s personal presence but also true statements and judgments given by God concerning himself, his works, and his will.

  - General revelation: “The heavens declare the glory of God,” such that what may be known of God is “clearly perceived” in the things that have been made.
  - Special revelation: God speaks in definite words, promises, commands, narratives, doctrines; Scripture is “the Word of God written” and is “the only rule of faith and obedience.”

  “Objective” here means that these truths are not merely projections of religious feeling or communal value-judgments; they confront the hearer as divinely given assertions that may be believed, obeyed, or rejected.

- **Independence from human subjectivity as norm.** Revelation is norming for, not normed by, human piety and experience.

  - Human religious consciousness is fallible and corrupted by sin; it is corrected and judged by God’s revelation.
  - The church’s faith and the believer’s “inner piety” are responses to revelation and are to be reformed according to Scripture, not the standard by which revelation is authenticated or delimited.

Putting this together: in Reformed usage, to call revelation “objective” is to say that the self-revealing triune God, with his determinate being and will, gives authoritative cognitive content in creation and in Scripture, which stands over against and above human subjectivity as its judge and rule.

## Schleiermacher and Barth in light of this clarification

With that clarified, the critique can be sharpened.

- **Schleiermacher.**
  
  - Ontologically, he does not deny God’s independent reality, but the locus of theology is decisively shifted: the essence of religion is the feeling of absolute dependence, and dogmatics systematizes the pious self-consciousness of the Christian community.
  - Propositional content becomes secondary and derivative, the expression of that feeling; doctrine is not primarily received divine assertion, but reflection on Christian consciousness.
  - Normativity runs from experience to doctrine: revelation is “recognized” only insofar as it heightens or purifies God-consciousness; Scripture’s authority is functional (its capacity to mediate that piety), not grounded in its being God’s objective Word.

  From a Reformed perspective, Schleiermacher thereby undermines the objectivity of revelation in all three senses: revelation is folded into religious subjectivity, doctrine loses its character as divinely given truth-claim, and Scripture no longer stands as an external, critical norm.

- **Barth.**
  
  - Barth is far closer to the Reformed concern for divine transcendence and initiative. God is not an aspect of human consciousness but the sovereign Subject who reveals himself in Jesus Christ.
  - He insists that God’s self-revelation is an event in which God really gives himself and truly speaks; this certainly maintains ontological objectivity.
  - However, because he sharply identifies revelation only with the free act of God in Christ (and in the Spirit’s present speaking), he is reluctant to say that revelation is stably inscripturated as objective propositional content. Scripture is a fallible human witness that can become God’s Word in the event of God’s speaking through it.

  Relative to Reformed confessionalism, Barth thus strongly affirms ontological objectivity and a robust independence of revelation from human religious feeling, but attenuates objectivity at the level of fixed, enduring propositional form in Scripture as such.

## Reformed alternative

Classic Reformed theology insists:

- God, ontologically independent, freely reveals himself in Christ and by the Spirit.
- That revelation intrinsically includes determinate truths, authoritatively expressed in human language in Scripture, whose meaning is not constituted by our response.
- The inner testimony of the Spirit grants faith and illumination, but does not constitute revelation; it opens the heart to receive an already objective Word.

So, when “objective revelation” is properly defined in these senses, the Reformed critique is that Schleiermacher effectively collapses revelation into human religious subjectivity, while Barth, though recovering God’s sovereign subjecthood, does not consistently ascribe full, stable objectivity to Scripture as revelation’s inscripturated form.

balance_issues.answer_markdown:
The issue is that Schleiermacher and Barth were largely treated as foils for a Reformed doctrine of revelation, so their own constructive intentions and inner coherence were underdeveloped, which risks caricature and prevents a more precise Reformed critique.

## Schleiermacher on Revelation on His Own Terms

Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation is governed by his reformulation of religion as **Gefühl**, the immediate self-consciousness of absolute dependence. Revelation is not primarily disclosure of propositional truths or metaphysical realities, but the event and structure of this God-related self-consciousness within the communal life of the church.

Key elements:

- **Anthropological starting point**  
  Schleiermacher does not begin from an independent doctrine of God or Scripture but from the analysis of human religious consciousness. Religion is neither knowing (metaphysics) nor doing (morality) but a distinct sphere: immediate awareness of being absolutely dependent.

- **Christ as the centre of revelation**  
  For Schleiermacher, revelation is concentrated in the **redeemer’s perfect God-consciousness**.  
    - In Christ the feeling of absolute dependence is unclouded and archetypal.  
    - Redemption consists in the communication of this God-consciousness to the community, so that the church’s piety is a historical extension of Christ’s.

- **Scripture and dogma as second-order**  
  Scripture is the normative description of the piety of the earliest Christian community, which most purely participated in Christ’s God-consciousness.  
    - It is “normative” because it stands at the origin of the communal life in which Christ’s consciousness is mediated.  
    - Doctrines are regulated expressions of this piety for the church’s edification, not revealed propositions in themselves.

- **Revelation and history**  
  Revelation is not a set of punctiliar supernatural intrusions but the historical life of Christ and the ongoing life of the Spirit-formed community. Miracles and supernatural events are interpreted, if at all, by their capacity to mediate and intensify God-consciousness.

From within this framework, Schleiermacher is not simply “denying special revelation”; he is redefining revelation as the inner, historical, communal actualization of Christ’s God-consciousness, with Scripture and doctrine as its normative articulation.

## Barth on Revelation on His Own Terms

Barth’s doctrine of revelation is governed by a radical **theological starting point**: God is who he is in his self-revelation in Jesus Christ, and this act is sovereign, free, and irreducible to human religious consciousness or natural reason.

Central structural elements:

- **Revelation as event of the triune God**  
  Revelation is God’s self-identification in the Christ-event.  
    - The Father is the Revealer, the Son is the Revelation, the Spirit is the power by which revelation is received.  
    - Revelation is not a deposit separable from the act; it is God’s own living self-presence.

- **Threefold form of the Word**  
  Barth distinguishes three coordinated forms:  
    - Jesus Christ as the **revealed Word**.  
    - Holy Scripture as the **written Word**, the normative prophetic-apostolic witness to Christ.  
    - Church proclamation as the **preached Word**, which, when and as God pleases, becomes a further form of this same witness.  
  In all three, God remains free: Scripture and preaching are Word only as and when God takes them up as instruments of his revealing.

- **Rejection of autonomous natural theology**  
  Barth’s famous “Nein” to Brunner is directed at any attempt to establish an independent point of contact in human nature or history upon which theology could build.  
    - He does not deny creaturely order or the reality of created signs, but he denies that these can be read theologically apart from God’s prior self-revelation in Christ.  
    - The knowledge of God is wholly grounded in grace, and thus revelation is identical with reconciliation.

- **Revelation and history**  
  While revelation occurs in history, it is not simply coextensive with “historical process.”  
    - Historical events become revelation only as they are identical with the free act of the triune God in Christ.  
    - This guards against equating providence, culture, or religious development with revelation itself.

On his own terms, Barth is not merely “denying general revelation” but reconfiguring the category: any true knowledge of God through the created order is already encompassed within and dependent upon the one revelation of God in Jesus Christ.

## Reformed Evaluation in Light of a Fair Presentation

From a classic Reformed standpoint (as articulated, for example, in confessional teaching on general and special revelation), one can now assess with more precision.

- **With Schleiermacher**  
  - Positively, his focus on the centrality of Christ and the church, and his recognition that revelation must actually reach and transform the subject, correspond to Reformed emphases on union with Christ and the internal testimony of the Spirit.  
  - Critically, by making revelation essentially identical with piety (God-consciousness), he collapses the order of knowing into the order of experience, relativizing the objectivity of God’s external self-disclosure in Word and act. The Reformed doctrine of revelation insists that the Spirit’s work in the subject presupposes and applies a prior, objective revelation in the acts and words of God recorded in Scripture.

- **With Barth**  
  - Positively, his Christocentrism, his insistence on God’s freedom and transcendence, and his critique of autonomous natural theology rescue revelation from captivity to culture and reason.  
  - Critically, by so identifying revelation with the living event of God’s self-speaking, he tends to weaken the stable, inscripturated character of special revelation and to subordinate the created order’s revelatory capacity more than classic Reformed theology allows. Reformed teaching affirms that Scripture is itself the Word of God written and that the created order truly and continuously manifests God, even though sinful man suppresses this revelation.

A balanced treatment thus acknowledges the genuine systematic coherence and theological concerns of both Schleiermacher and Barth before subjecting their doctrines of revelation to Reformed confessional critique.

Barth’s doctrine of revelation is governed by a radical theological starting point: God is who he is in his self-revelation in Jesus Christ, and this act is sovereign, free, and irreducible to human religious consciousness or natural reason.

Central structural elements:

  • Revelation as event of the triune God
    Revelation is God’s self-identification in the Christ-event.

    • The Father is the Revealer, the Son is the Revelation, the Spirit is the power by which revelation is received.
    • Revelation is not a deposit separable from the act; it is God’s own living self-presence.

  • Threefold form of the Word
    Barth distinguishes three coordinated forms:

    • Jesus Christ as the revealed Word.
    • Holy Scripture as the written Word, the normative prophetic-apostolic witness to Christ.
    • Church proclamation as the preached Word, which, when and as God pleases, becomes a further form of this same witness.
      In all three, God remains free: Scripture and preaching are Word only as and when God takes them up as instruments of his revealing.

  • Rejection of autonomous natural theology
    Barth’s famous “Nein” to Brunner is directed at any attempt to establish an independent point of contact in human nature or history upon which theology could build.

    • He does not deny creaturely order or the reality of created signs, but he denies that these can be read theologically apart from God’s prior self-revelation in Christ.
    • The knowledge of God is wholly grounded in grace, and thus revelation is identical with reconciliation.

  • Revelation and history
    While revelation occurs in history, it is not simply coextensive with “historical process.”

    • Historical events become revelation only as they are identical with the free act of the triune God in Christ.
    • This guards against equating providence, culture, or religious development with revelation itself.

On his own terms, Barth is not merely “denying general revelation” but reconfiguring the category: any true knowledge of God through the created order is already encompassed within and dependent upon the one revelation of God in Jesus Christ.

Reformed Evaluation in Light of a Fair Presentation

From a classic Reformed standpoint (as articulated, for example, in confessional teaching on general and special revelation), one can now assess with more precision.

  • With Schleiermacher
  • Positively, his focus on the centrality of Christ and the church, and his recognition that revelation must actually reach and transform the subject, correspond to Reformed emphases on union with Christ and the internal testimony of the Spirit.

  • Critically, by making revelation essentially identical with piety (God-consciousness), he collapses the order of knowing into the order of experience, relativizing the objectivity of God’s external self-disclosure in Word and act. The Reformed doctrine of revelation insists that the Spirit’s work in the subject presupposes and applies a prior, objective revelation in the acts and words of God recorded in Scripture.

  • With Barth

  • Positively, his Christocentrism, his insistence on God’s freedom and transcendence, and his critique of autonomous natural theology rescue revelation from captivity to culture and reason.
  • Critically, by so identifying revelation with the living event of God’s self-speaking, he tends to weaken the stable, inscripturated character of special revelation and to subordinate the created order’s revelatory capacity more than classic Reformed theology allows. Reformed teaching affirms that Scripture is itself the Word of God written and that the created order truly and continuously manifests God, even though sinful man suppresses this revelation.

A balanced treatment thus acknowledges the genuine systematic coherence and theological concerns of both Schleiermacher and Barth before subjecting their doctrines of revelation to Reformed confessional critique.

balance_issues.answer_markdown:
The issue is that Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation was handled largely at the level of slogans about “feeling” and “subjective experience,” without working through his systematic account in The Christian Faith, so that Barth received a more theologically serious and detailed exposition than Schleiermacher.

## Schleiermacher’s Dogmatic Location of Revelation

In The Christian Faith, Schleiermacher frames all dogmatics as a description of the Christian church’s “pious self-consciousness.” Doctrine does not state revealed propositions given by God; it analyzes and orders the states of religious consciousness that actually obtain in the Christian community.

Within that framework:

- **Revelation is not primarily propositional disclosure** of divine truths; it is the occurrence and communication of a specific form of God-consciousness.
- The **essence of religion** is the “feeling of absolute dependence,” a pre-reflective, universal structure of human consciousness; Christian faith is the historically determinate modification of this universal religious feeling by the person and community of Christ.
- Dogmatic statements are **second-order, reflective articulations** of this pious consciousness, not revealed data to be believed because God said them.

Thus “revelation” in systematic terms is the concrete historical emergence, in and through Christ and his community, of the highest form of God-consciousness, and the continuing communication of that consciousness in the church.

## Christ and Revelation in The Christian Faith

Schleiermacher gives Christological concentration to revelation, but in a distinct way:

- Christ is not primarily the ontic self-revelation of the Triune God in history; rather, he is the human in whom **God-consciousness is perfect, constant, and archetypal**.
- The “revelatory” character of Christ lies in the **redemptive causality of his God-consciousness**: by his influence on the community, this perfect God-consciousness is communicated, in derivative and varying forms, to believers.
- Justification and reconciliation are therefore construed as changes in the **state of consciousness** of the community, grounded in Christ’s original God-consciousness.
- Revelation is thus **teleological and experiential**: what counts as revelatory is what actually generates and deepens this God-consciousness within the communal life of faith.

From a Reformed standpoint, this relocates revelation from God’s self-communication in word and deed to the subjective and communal reception construed as a distinctive mode of feeling.

## Scripture, Church, and the Form of Revelation

In The Christian Faith, Schleiermacher develops a more precise account of Scripture and the church than a brief summary easily conveys:

- Scripture is the **normative record** of the earliest and most originary expressions of Christian God-consciousness, especially as shaped by Christ and the apostles.
- Its normativity is **functional and historical**, not ontological: it is the “original document” of the church’s piety, not an inspired corpus of divinely given truths.
- Inspiration is not a special, supernatural act conferring inerrant authority; it designates the **religious superiority** of biblical authors’ God-consciousness relative to later believers.
- The church itself, as the ongoing community in which Christ’s God-consciousness is propagated, is the **living bearer** of revelation; doctrine and Scripture serve that living process.

Thus the formal norm in Schleiermacher’s system is the **actual piety of the Christian community** as historically mediated and critically described; Scripture’s authority is subordinated to and interpreted through the life of the church’s consciousness.

## Reformed Evaluation

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint:

- Schleiermacher’s centering of revelation in **God-consciousness** displaces the Reformed understanding of revelation as God’s self-attesting, verbal and historical self-disclosure, culminating in Christ and inscripturated by the Spirit.
- His reduction of dogmatics to a **descriptive science of piety** undermines the principial role of Scripture as *norma normans*, the external Word by which the church is constituted and judged.
- The Christological focus is formally significant but materially deficient, because Christ mediates God-consciousness rather than **reconciling sinners by objective saving acts and interpreted promises**; what is “revealed” is not primarily who God is and what he has done, but a perfected form of human religious life.
- Natural and special revelation are no longer distinct divine modes of self-disclosure; they are different intensities and specifications of the **same basic religious structure** of consciousness, thereby eroding the Creator–creature distinction that undergirds Reformed accounts of revelation.

In sum, Schleiermacher’s systematic doctrine in The Christian Faith relocates revelation from God’s sovereign, verbal self-disclosure to the evolving self-consciousness of the church, a move that Reformed theology must reject as a fundamental inversion of the order between God’s Word and human experience.

balance_issues.answer_markdown:
The issue is that Barth’s doctrine of revelation in my account was effectively frozen at his early “dialectical” stage (Römerbrief and the Brunner debate), so that his most radical, polemical formulations were foregrounded without doing justice to the more elaborate and internally nuanced account of revelation in the Church Dogmatics. In other words, I described “early Barth against natural theology” more than “mature Barth on the triune God’s self-revelation,” and so the comparison with Schleiermacher was skewed and underdeveloped at the very point of greatest dogmatic interest.

## Barth’s Mature Doctrine of Revelation in Church Dogmatics

Barth’s definitive account is concentrated in Church Dogmatics I/1–I/2. Several clarifications are essential.

- **Revelation as triune self-unveiling.**  
  Revelation is not a deposit of information alongside God; it is God himself in his free self-presence. Barth thematizes revelation, reconciliation, and redemption as one divine act in different aspects. In CD I/1, the triune structure is explicit:  
    - God is the **revealer** (the Father as source).  
    - God is the **revelation** (the Son as the content, the Word).  
    - God is the **revealedness** (the Spirit making this revelation present and effective).  
  Revelation is therefore strictly personal and trinitarian, not a general category into which God merely happens to fit.

- **The threefold form of the Word of God.**  
  Barth’s well-known schema is refined and carefully ordered:
    - First, Jesus Christ himself is the **Word of God in person**, the original and primary revelation.  
    - Second, **Holy Scripture** is the written Word of God because it is the prophetic-apostolic testimony elected and commissioned to attest Christ.  
    - Third, **church proclamation** is the Word of God in a derivative, contingent way when and as God is pleased to use it as an instrument of Christ’s self-witness.  

  Barth is emphatic that all three “forms” are genuinely the Word of God, but in an ordered way: Christ as the norming norm, Scripture as the normative witness, proclamation as conditioned by both. The earlier essay’s emphasis on “Scripture only as witness” risks muting Barth’s real affirmation that Scripture is indeed Word of God in its unique office.

- **Revelation and Scripture: objectivity and event.**  
  Barth wants to deny that Scripture is an **inherent, static possession** of revelation, but he does not reduce it to pure subjectivity.  
    - Scripture is a concrete historical object that God has taken into service.  
    - Its “becoming” the Word of God in the Spirit does not mean it sometimes is and sometimes is not the Word in an arbitrary sense; rather, the church is directed to these writings as the place where God has bound himself to speak.  
  This produces a complex dialectic: Scripture is both fallible human testimony and uniquely, divinely sanctioned canon, the place of normative encounter. My earlier emphasis on witness without this dialectic risks making Barth sound merely Schleiermacherian at this point.

- **Refined stance toward natural theology.**  
  Barth never retracts the “Nein” to an independent natural theology, but in CD I/1–II/1 his position is more sophisticated than a sheer denial of all creaturely knowledge of God.  
    - He distinguishes between a **revelation of God in Jesus Christ alone**, and a **secondary, derivative “parables of the kingdom”** in creation and history that can only be seen as such from the standpoint of faith in Christ.  
    - In CD II/1, the doctrine of election and of the divine perfection of **lordship and freedom** governs his understanding of how God can make creaturely realities serve as witnesses.  

  Thus Barth does not say there is no genuine creaturely testimony at all; he says there is no usable, theologically norming knowledge of God available apart from and outside God’s self-revelation in Christ. The polemical “No” to natural theology is a “No” to a second, independent source of saving or doctrinally constructive knowledge, not to all vestiges of the knowledge of God.

## Reformed Evaluation and Correction of the Imbalance

From a classic Reformed standpoint, several corrections and appropriations follow.

- **Affirmation of the central Christological and trinitarian insight.**  
  Barth’s insistence that revelation is the triune God’s own act, centered in the person and work of Christ, accords with Reformed insistence that all saving knowledge of God is mediated through the Son and applied by the Spirit, not gained by autonomous speculation.

- **Necessary clarification on Scripture.**  
  Reformed orthodoxy maintains that Holy Scripture is, in itself and by divine inspiration, the written Word of God, the sufficient, clear, and inerrant norm of all saving knowledge and obedience.  
    - Barth’s dynamic account rightly stresses the living Lord who speaks through the text.  
    - Yet Reformed theology resists his hesitancy to ascribe infallible propositional authority to Scripture as such, because it undermines the covenantal objectivity necessary for assurance, doctrine, and ecclesial discipline.

- **Qualified reception of his critique of natural theology.**  
  Reformed theology agrees that there is no second, independent source of redemptive knowledge alongside Scripture and Christ, and that fallen reason cannot construct a true theology of salvation.  
    - At the same time, it upholds a genuine **general revelation** in creation and conscience that renders humanity without excuse and that, when regenerated and normed by Scripture, can be theologically elaborated (for example, in arguments from creation, providence, and morality).  
    - Barth’s mature recognition of creaturely “parables” of revelation is a partial convergence, but he does not fully integrate this with a robust doctrine of general revelation as in classic Reformed confessions.

In sum, a balanced account of Barth must treat his mature Church Dogmatics doctrine of revelation as a trinitarian, Christocentric, and Word-structured event that, while remaining problematic on Scripture’s inerrancy and general revelation, is more nuanced and theologically constructive than his early radical dialectical formulations alone would suggest.

balance_issues.answer_markdown:
The issue is that the essay ended with a blanket rejection of both Schleiermacher and Barth on revelation, with only a cursory nod to Reformed appropriation, instead of offering a discriminating evaluation that does justice to the comparative work and to genuine points of convergence and divergence with classic Reformed doctrine.

## Doctrinal baseline: classic Reformed view of revelation

From a confessional Reformed standpoint (e.g. Westminster Standards, Three Forms of Unity), the key affirmations are:

- **Twofold revelation**: God reveals himself in creation and providence (general revelation) and in Christ through Scripture (special revelation).
- **Reality and insufficiency of general revelation**: General revelation truly discloses God’s eternal power and divine nature, and renders humanity without excuse, but it is not sufficient for saving knowledge.
- **Supernatural, verbal, and inscripturated special revelation**: God has given a redemptive revelation centered in Christ, first by acts and words in history, then committed infallibly to writing in Scripture by inspiration of the Spirit.
- **Objectivity and clarity**: Because Scripture is God-breathed, it is the external, objective norm and possesses a genuine perspicuity in matters necessary for salvation, though it must be illumined by the Spirit to be rightly received.
- **Role of experience and church**: The Spirit grants faith and inward illumination; the church receives, transmits, and proclaims the Word, but neither experience nor church constitute revelation itself.

This provides the evaluative grid for assessing Schleiermacher and Barth.

## Schleiermacher: evaluation and differentiated appropriation

Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation relocates revelation into religious self-consciousness and communal piety:

- **Critical divergences**:
  - By grounding revelation in the “feeling of absolute dependence” and the piety of the Christian community, he effectively inverts the Reformed order: revelation is no longer God’s sovereign self-disclosure that generates faith, but is largely identified with the structure of consciousness and its historical expressions.
  - Scripture becomes the normative expression of ecclesial consciousness rather than the inspired, verbally given Word of God; its authority is functional and historical, not ontological and infallible.
  - General and special revelation are blurred: “revelation” names a universal religious dimension rather than a distinct, covenantal self-disclosure in redemptive history.

- **Partial insights that can be appropriated**:
  - His insistence that faith is not reducible to mere assent to propositions rightly recalls that revelation is unto communion with God, not mere cognition.
  - His placement of revelation in the life of the church, rather than as a collection of abstract data, underscores rightly that revelation is ordered to a concrete community and its worship.

From a Reformed standpoint, however, these insights can only be received if sharply re-ordered: experience and ecclesial life are fruits and spheres of revelation, not its essence or norm, and they must be subordinated to the objective, inspired Word.

## Barth: evaluation and differentiated appropriation

Barth is in many respects closer to a Reformed doctrine of revelation, yet departs in crucial respects.

- **Significant convergences**:
  - His Christocentrism echoes and intensifies the confessional claim that Christ is the substance of Scripture and the mediator of all saving knowledge of God; revelation is fundamentally God’s free act in Christ, not a human religious achievement.
  - His polemic against autonomous natural theology, especially any claim to saving knowledge apart from Christ, aligns with Reformed fears of rationalism, Pelagianism, and theological speculation cut loose from Scripture.
  - His emphasis on the triune structure of revelation—God as the revealer, the act of revelation, and the content of revelation—resonates with the Reformed insistence that revelation is a personal, triune self-disclosure.

- **Critical divergences**:
  - By insisting that revelation is strictly identical with the living act of God in Christ’s self-witness, and then treating Scripture as a fallible human witness that may become revelation, Barth destabilizes the confessional identification of Scripture as the Word of God written.
  - His programmatic rejection of natural theology tends to collapse general revelation into either idolatry or irrelevance; the Reformed confessions instead affirm a true but non-saving general revelation, distorted but not annihilated by sin.
  - The event-character of revelation in Barth can threaten the durably given, covenantal form of revelation in canon and creed, rendering the church’s access to revelation more precarious than Reformed theology allows.

Yet, with doctrinal correction, Barth’s emphases can be fruitfully appropriated: his stress on God’s sovereign initiative, on the christological center, and on the priority of God’s act over human response all reinforce core Reformed commitments when anchored in a more robust doctrine of Scripture and general revelation.

## Reframed conclusion from a Reformed standpoint

A more adequate conclusion would neither simply reject both theologians nor collapse them together, but would state:

- Schleiermacher represents a decisive departure from Reformed doctrine of revelation by locating revelation fundamentally in human consciousness and ecclesial piety, though his insistence on the experiential and communal dimensions of faith exposes real blind spots in merely formal orthodoxy.
- Barth partially recovers central Reformed instincts—divine initiative, Christocentrism, anti-rationalism, trinitarian structure—while, from a confessional perspective, erring in his refusal of a real, though limited, general revelation and in his reluctance to affirm Scripture as infallible, ontologically revelatory Word.

From a classic Reformed standpoint, then, Schleiermacher’s theology of revelation must be largely rejected and Barth’s critically received and corrected, yet elements in both can be integrated as subordinate insights into a doctrine of revelation grounded in God’s triune self-disclosure in nature, in Christ, and in the Spirit-inspired Scriptures.
