  • Objectivity and clarity: Because Scripture is God-breathed, it is the external, objective norm and possesses a genuine perspicuity in matters necessary for salvation, though it must be illumined by the Spirit to be rightly received.
  • Role of experience and church: The Spirit grants faith and inward illumination; the church receives, transmits, and proclaims the Word, but neither experience nor church constitute revelation itself.

This provides the evaluative grid for assessing Schleiermacher and Barth.

Schleiermacher: evaluation and differentiated appropriation

Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation relocates revelation into religious self-consciousness and communal piety:

  • Critical divergences:
  • By grounding revelation in the “feeling of absolute dependence” and the piety of the Christian community, he effectively inverts the Reformed order: revelation is no longer God’s sovereign self-disclosure that generates faith, but is largely identified with the structure of consciousness and its historical expressions.
  • Scripture becomes the normative expression of ecclesial consciousness rather than the inspired, verbally given Word of God; its authority is functional and historical, not ontological and infallible.

  • General and special revelation are blurred: “revelation” names a universal religious dimension rather than a distinct, covenantal self-disclosure in redemptive history.

  • Partial insights that can be appropriated:

  • His insistence that faith is not reducible to mere assent to propositions rightly recalls that revelation is unto communion with God, not mere cognition.
  • His placement of revelation in the life of the church, rather than as a collection of abstract data, underscores rightly that revelation is ordered to a concrete community and its worship.

From a Reformed standpoint, however, these insights can only be received if sharply re-ordered: experience and ecclesial life are fruits and spheres of revelation, not its essence or norm, and they must be subordinated to the objective, inspired Word.

Barth: evaluation and differentiated appropriation

Barth is in many respects closer to a Reformed doctrine of revelation, yet departs in crucial respects.

  • Significant convergences:
  • His Christocentrism echoes and intensifies the confessional claim that Christ is the substance of Scripture and the mediator of all saving knowledge of God; revelation is fundamentally God’s free act in Christ, not a human religious achievement.
  • His polemic against autonomous natural theology, especially any claim to saving knowledge apart from Christ, aligns with Reformed fears of rationalism, Pelagianism, and theological speculation cut loose from Scripture.

  • His emphasis on the triune structure of revelation—God as the revealer, the act of revelation, and the content of revelation—resonates with the Reformed insistence that revelation is a personal, triune self-disclosure.

  • Critical divergences:

  • By insisting that revelation is strictly identical with the living act of God in Christ’s self-witness, and then treating Scripture as a fallible human witness that may become revelation, Barth destabilizes the confessional identification of Scripture as the Word of God written.
  • His programmatic rejection of natural theology tends to collapse general revelation into either idolatry or irrelevance; the Reformed confessions instead affirm a true but non-saving general revelation, distorted but not annihilated by sin.
  • The event-character of revelation in Barth can threaten the durably given, covenantal form of revelation in canon and creed, rendering the church’s access to revelation more precarious than Reformed theology allows.

Yet, with doctrinal correction, Barth’s emphases can be fruitfully appropriated: his stress on God’s sovereign initiative, on the christological center, and on the priority of God’s act over human response all reinforce core Reformed commitments when anchored in a more robust doctrine of Scripture and general revelation.

Reframed conclusion from a Reformed standpoint

A more adequate conclusion would neither simply reject both theologians nor collapse them together, but would state:

  • Schleiermacher represents a decisive departure from Reformed doctrine of revelation by locating revelation fundamentally in human consciousness and ecclesial piety, though his insistence on the experiential and communal dimensions of faith exposes real blind spots in merely formal orthodoxy.
  • Barth partially recovers central Reformed instincts—divine initiative, Christocentrism, anti-rationalism, trinitarian structure—while, from a confessional perspective, erring in his refusal of a real, though limited, general revelation and in his reluctance to affirm Scripture as infallible, ontologically revelatory Word.

From a classic Reformed standpoint, then, Schleiermacher’s theology of revelation must be largely rejected and Barth’s critically received and corrected, yet elements in both can be integrated as subordinate insights into a doctrine of revelation grounded in God’s triune self-disclosure in nature, in Christ, and in the Spirit-inspired Scriptures.

balance_issues.source_note: The focus on Scripture and natural revelation sidelines other crucial comparative loci such as Christology, ecclesiology, and the role of the Holy Spirit in revelation, resulting in a narrow and incomplete comparison.
balance_issues.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/balance_issues:

The focus on Scripture and natural revelation sidelines other crucial comparative loci such as Christology, ecclesiology, and the role of the Holy Spirit in revelation, resulting in a narrow and incomplete comparison.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
balance_issues.answer_markdown:
The issue is that the comparison of Barth and Schleiermacher on revelation was largely restricted to Scripture and natural theology, leaving underdeveloped how their different doctrines of Christ, the church, and the Spirit structure their entire accounts of revelation. A fuller comparison must show how these loci interlock, and then evaluate them from a classic Reformed standpoint.

## Christology and Revelation

For Schleiermacher, Christ is the locus of revelation in a fundamentally anthropological and soteriological key.

- Christ is the unique bearer of a perfect, uninterrupted **God-consciousness**.
- Revelation consists in the historical manifestation and communicability of this God-consciousness within the community.
- The incarnation is not primarily the hypostatic union of two natures as in Chalcedonian and Reformed orthodoxy, but the unsurpassed, archetypal realization of what “religion” essentially is: immediate consciousness of absolute dependence.

Thus, revelation in Schleiermacher is mediated through a human subject whose uniqueness is qualitative but still construed within the grammar of religious experience. Ontological Trinitarian and christological determinations recede behind phenomenology of consciousness.

Barth radically re-centers revelation onto the ontological event of God’s self-giving in Christ.

- Christ is not just the supreme instance of religious consciousness but **God himself in his self-interpretation**.
- In the Christ-event, God is simultaneously Revealer, Revelation, and Revealedness.
- The incarnation is the once-for-all act in which the eternal Son assumes flesh; revelation is therefore intrinsically **Trinitarian and christological**, not primarily experiential.

From a Reformed standpoint, Barth’s movement is formally closer to the classic doctrine: revelation is grounded in the hypostatic union and the mediatorial office of Christ, not in a religious Genius; Schleiermacher’s Christology dissolves the ontological scandal of the incarnation into the highest form of piety.

## Ecclesiology and Revelation

Both theologians tie revelation to the church, but in profoundly different ways.

For Schleiermacher:

- The church is the **communion of God-consciousness**, the ongoing life of piety generated by Christ.
- Revelation is in practice coextensive with the history of Christian experience in the community.
- Doctrine, confessions, and Scripture function as **second-order descriptions** of the community’s inner life, not as externally authoritative, once-for-all norms.

Revelation thus becomes, in effect, ecclesial self-understanding: the church’s consciousness of dependence as shaped by the normative origin in Christ and the apostolic community.

For Barth:

- The church is not itself revelation but the **sphere where the Word-event happens**.
- The threefold form of the Word (incarnate, written, proclaimed) is entrusted to the church, yet remains sovereign over it.
- The church’s task is to hear and witness; it is judged and constituted by the Word rather than being the constitutive subject of revelation.

From a Reformed perspective, Schleiermacher’s model collapses the principium externum (objective Word) into the principium internum (experience of faith) and so undermines the church’s subjection to the canon. Barth, while rejecting an identification of Scripture with revelation, nevertheless preserves a strong asymmetry: church and proclamation are instruments of a Word that is not reducible to ecclesial life. Reformed orthodoxy sides with that asymmetry, but insists more strongly than Barth on Scripture as objectively, covenantally given revelation.

## Pneumatology and Revelation

The role of the Spirit is decisive for how revelation is both given and received.

Schleiermacher’s pneumatology is essentially **immanent and experiential**:

- The Spirit is primarily the **Spirit of the community**, the shared life of God-consciousness.
- Inspiration and illumination are understood as the intensification, clarification, and communication of pious feeling within the church.
- The Spirit’s work is not chiefly to bind hearers to a fixed, prior divine discourse, but to actualize religious self-consciousness.

This reinforces the tendency to internalize revelation: the Spirit does not principally open the heart to an external Word but deepens an already-granted religious structure of consciousness.

Barth’s pneumatology, by contrast, is **Word-related and event-structured**:

- The Spirit is the act by which God makes the written and preached Word **actual revelation here and now**, uniting us to Christ.
- Revelation is not a latent human capacity; it is a free, disruptive act of God in which the Spirit gives faith, hearing, and obedience.
- The Spirit’s work is inseparable from the history of Jesus Christ; there is no independent religious a priori to which the Spirit simply adds intensity.

From a Reformed standpoint, Barth’s emphasis that the Spirit binds us to Christ through the external Word is materially closer to the classic doctrine of the Spirit as the internal witness who authenticates and applies the once-for-all inscripturated revelation; Schleiermacher’s identification of the Spirit with the corporate religious life of the church blurs the distinction between divine initiative and human religiosity.

## Integrated Reformed Evaluation

When Christology, ecclesiology, and pneumatology are set alongside Scripture and natural revelation, the structural differences sharpen.

- Schleiermacher runs a single line: from a **universal structure of religious consciousness**, through Christ as its perfect historical embodiment, into the church as the community of shared God-consciousness, animated by a Spirit largely identified with that communal life. Revelation is the reflexive awareness of this process.
- Barth runs a different line: from the **sovereign Trinitarian act** in Christ, through the canonically mediated Word, into the church as the judged and gathered community, vivified by the Spirit who freely actualizes revelation in hearing and faith.

Classic Reformed theology agrees with Barth against Schleiermacher that revelation is first God’s objective triune self-disclosure in Christ and by the Spirit through the external Word, received in the church, and only then an experience of faith, not vice versa.

missing_figures.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under omissions/missing_figures:

No engagement with Reformed theologians central to the doctrine of revelation such as John Calvin, B B Warfield, Herman Bavinck, or Cornelius Van Til, despite the Reformed evaluative framework.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
missing_figures.answer_markdown:
The concern is that the comparison of Schleiermacher and Barth on revelation was conducted from a supposedly Reformed standpoint without bringing into view the central Reformed exponents of revelation doctrine—Calvin, Warfield, Bavinck, Van Til—so that the “Reformed” evaluation lacked a clearly articulated confessional baseline.

## Classic Reformed Locus of Revelation

From a confessional Reformed standpoint (e.g., Westminster, Three Forms of Unity), several structural commitments define the doctrine of revelation:

- **Twofold revelation: general and special.**  
  God reveals himself in creation and providence to all humans (Ps 19; Rom 1), rendering them without excuse, and reveals himself salvifically in Christ through Scripture.

- **Objectivity and verbal character.**  
  God’s revelatory activity is not reducible to religious feeling or ecclesial consciousness; it is God’s self-disclosure in acts and in the interpretive Word, culminating in Christ and inscripturated in the prophets and apostles.

- **Organic relation of Christ and Scripture.**  
  Christ is the ontological center of revelation; Scripture is the God-given, Spirit-breathed, sufficient and inerrant form in which that revelation is normatively accessible in the present economy.

This structure is given classic form in Calvin, systematized and defended in Warfield and Bavinck, and epistemologically sharpened in Van Til.

## Calvin

Calvin grounds revelation in:

- **Sensus divinitatis and general revelation.**  
  All humans possess an inborn awareness of God and encounter his revelation in the “theater” of creation, yet suppress this knowledge in unrighteousness.

- **Scripture as spectacles.**  
  Because of sin, general revelation never yields true saving knowledge; Scripture, as God’s own speech, functions as “spectacles” by which the confused perception of God in nature is brought into focus.

- **Authority and clarity of Scripture.**  
  Scripture is self-authenticating, bearing divine authority and clarity, with the Spirit’s internal testimony enabling reception; its origin and normativity are divine, not ecclesial or experiential.

Thus Calvin sharply distinguishes revelation from religious experience (contra Schleiermacher) while binding revelation to the written Word without collapsing it into the book as an autonomous object (contra certain crude biblicisms).

## Warfield

Warfield articulates the mature Old Princeton form of Reformed bibliology:

- **Inspiration and inerrancy.**  
  Scripture is “God-breathed” in its entirety; inspiration extends to the words, ensuring that the resultant text is without error in all that it affirms.

- **Revelation and inspiration distinguished but coordinated.**  
  Revelation is God’s making known of truth; inspiration is God’s superintendence of the recording so that the product is his Word. The inscripturated revelation is not mere witness but the revelation in its normative, covenantal form.

- **Rejection of subjectivism and pure event-ontology.**  
  Warfield explicitly resists the move—prototypical in Schleiermacher and later in Barth—to detach revelation from the stable, verbal deposit and to relocate it in religious consciousness or in a non-propositional “event.”

Warfield therefore provides the precise doctrinal antithesis to Schleiermacher’s reduction of Scripture to ecclesial experience and to Barth’s sharp revelation/Scripture disjunction.

## Bavinck

Bavinck offers an organic, Christocentric version of the same Reformed structure:

- **Unity of general and special revelation.**  
  Creation and redemption are from the same triune God; general revelation is real and positive but, under sin, becomes condemnatory rather than saving apart from special revelation.

- **Revelation as both deed and word.**  
  God’s acts in history and his interpretive Word belong together; Scripture is the divinely ordered concentration and preservation of the revelatory Word.

- **Christ and Scripture.**  
  Christ is the fullness of revelation; yet we know this Christ only as attested in the apostolic and prophetic Scriptures, which, because inspired, are wholly trustworthy and authoritative.

Bavinck’s emphasis on the organic unity of act and word allows a strong doctrine of revelation as event (in redemptive history) without separating that event from its inspired textual form, thus correcting both Schleiermacher’s experiential reduction and Barth’s existentializing of the “event.”

## Van Til

Van Til extends this tradition into a presuppositional, epistemological key:

- **Revelation as covenantal and comprehensive.**  
  All knowledge is covenantal: there is no neutral territory. General revelation always confronts the sinner as covenant-breaker; special revelation in Christ and Scripture restores true knowledge.

- **Antithesis and analogy.**  
  Knowledge of God is analogical: genuinely true yet never exhaustive. Natural theology construed as autonomous reasoning from nature to God is ruled out, but natural revelation as God’s constant self-disclosure is affirmed.

- **Scripture as the principium cognoscendi of theology.**  
  Scripture, as self-attesting revelation, is the foundational epistemic authority. Religious experience, church proclamation, and theological reasoning have derivative and subordinate roles.

Van Til thus explicitly rejects Schleiermacher’s subjectivism and any appeal to a supposed “natural” point of contact independent of God’s covenantal revelation, while also criticizing Barth for undermining the objectivity and perspicuity of biblical revelation by his event-centered doctrine of the Word.

## Reformed Evaluation of Schleiermacher and Barth

Placed against this confessional trajectory:

- **Schleiermacher** displaces revelation from God’s objective speech and acts to the structure of religious consciousness and communal piety. From a Reformed standpoint:
  
  - He denies the full theological weight of general revelation as an objective divine disclosure.
  - He relativizes Scripture’s status as God’s own Word, treating it as normative expression of consciousness rather than inspired revelation.
  - He makes the criterion of revelation the augmentation of piety rather than the authoritative self-attestation of God.

- **Barth** rightly rejects the liberal subjectivism and affirms God’s sovereign self-revelation in Christ, yet:

  - He collapses special revelation into an elusive Christ-event not stably identified with the canonical text.
  - He refuses to ascribe to Scripture the status of revelation per se, speaking instead of a fallible human witness that can become the Word of God.
  - He effectively nullifies the classic Reformed doctrine of general revelation by his “Nein” to any natural knowledge of God, even in an essentially condemnatory mode.

Measured by Calvin, Warfield, Bavinck, and Van Til, a classic Reformed doctrine of revelation insists that the triune God objectively reveals himself in general and special revelation, with Christ as the center and Scripture as the inspired, inerrant, self-authenticating Word that normatively communicates that revelation to the church.

missing_figures.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under omissions/missing_figures:

Absence of discussion of mediating figures between Schleiermacher and Barth such as Albrecht Ritschl or Wilhelm Herrmann, who are important for understanding Barth’s reaction to liberalism.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
missing_figures.answer_markdown:
The issue is that the comparison of Schleiermacher and Barth on revelation jumped directly from Schleiermacher’s early nineteenth-century liberalism to Barth’s “dialectical” turn, without explaining the mediating liberal developments in figures such as Albrecht Ritschl and Wilhelm Herrmann, whose theologies decisively shaped the particular form of liberalism Barth opposed.

## Historical setting

Between Schleiermacher and Barth, nineteenth-century Protestantism underwent a series of internal revisions that produced the **Ritschlian school**:

- **Schleiermacher** grounded theology in the pre-reflective feeling of absolute dependence and the correlating self-consciousness of the Christian community.
- **Ritschl** rejected speculative metaphysics, but also resisted Schleiermacher’s psychological inwardness, recasting Christianity as the historical community of the Kingdom of God and theology as value-judgments about God’s action in history.
- **Herrmann**, Ritschl’s student and Barth’s own revered teacher at first, radicalized the emphasis on the **immediacy of the encounter with Christ** in the believer’s moral consciousness.

This trajectory created precisely the “liberal orthodoxy” Barth initially embraced and then repudiated in light of the First World War and the collapse of Kulturprotestantismus.

## Doctrinal analysis

### Albrecht Ritschl

Ritschl’s significance for revelation lies in three moves:

- **Historical-ethical reduction**: Revelation is not primarily propositional disclosure of divine being, but God’s self-giving in the history of Jesus as it bears on the moral vocation of the Kingdom of God.
- **Value-judgment epistemology**: Theological statements are not theoretical descriptions of divine essence but judgments expressing the value of God’s action for the community’s moral-religious life.
- **Rejection of metaphysics and natural theology**: Like Schleiermacher, Ritschl repudiates natural theology and ontological speculation; yet his criterion of truth is the practical fruit for the Kingdom.

- A critique of rationalist natural theology detached from Christ.

- The evacuation of revelation as truthful, cognitive self-disclosure of the living God in his being and works.
- The subordination of dogmatic content to pragmatic-ethical usefulness.

Herrmann stood closer to Schleiermacher in stressing **immediate religious experience**, but now configured by Ritschlian ethics:

- **Encounter with the historical Christ**: Revelation is the immediate impression made by the figure of Jesus in the Gospels on the individual, awakening a new moral certainty of God’s forgiving love.
- **Subjective immediacy**: The locus of revelation is my conscience confronted by the person of Jesus; doctrinal formulations are secondary, expressing that experience.
- **Historical-critical accommodation**: The “picture” of Jesus in Scripture, not the full factual accuracy of the narratives, is sufficient as the medium for this encounter.

For Barth as a young student, Herrmann embodied a profound seriousness about Christ while fully accepting modern criticism. But doctrinally, revelation is again **collapsed into religious experience of Christ’s moral power**, not proclamation of God’s objective act of judgment and grace.

From a Reformed viewpoint, Herrmann’s emphasis that Christ must be personally encountered resonates in part with the Reformed concern for faith as fiducia; yet:

- He effectively detaches this encounter from a robust doctrine of Scripture as God’s inerrant speech.
- He renders the content of revelation dependent on the structure of moral consciousness rather than on God’s sovereign self-interpretation in word and act.

Barth’s early dialectical theology cannot be understood as a simple negation of Schleiermacher; it is a **crisis within Ritschlian-Herrmannian liberalism**:

- Barth had absorbed Ritschl’s and Herrmann’s suspicion of metaphysics and natural theology, and their centering of theology on Christ and the community.
- The theological catastrophe of 1914–18, when his teachers endorsed nationalist war-ideology, convinced him that a theology grounded in human moral consciousness and cultural “values” is inherently pliable to ideology.
- Consequently, his Römerbrief and later Church Dogmatics reconfigure revelation as **God’s free, sovereign address in Jesus Christ**, breaking into and judging all human religion, experience, and ethics, including liberal Protestantism itself.

Thus Barth’s famous “Nein” to natural theology and his insistence that God is known only in his self-revelation in Christ are not merely anti-Schleiermacher; they are a repudiation of a century-long liberal move to locate revelation within:

- the structures of human **feeling** (Schleiermacher),
- the community’s **ethical value-judgments** (Ritschl),
- and the individual’s **moral-religious experience** (Herrmann).

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, acknowledging Ritschl and Herrmann clarifies that Barth is a partial corrective arising from within liberalism, recovering decisive Reformation themes of the objectivity, sovereignty, and judgment of God’s Word, even while he fails to recover fully the Reformed doctrines of Scripture’s inspiration and of a rightly ordered, subordinate natural revelation.

The omission of Ritschl and Herrmann thus obscured that Barth’s doctrine of revelation is a targeted reaction against a specific liberal trajectory in which revelation had been steadily reduced to ethically or experientially mediated human consciousness rather than God’s self-attesting speech in Christ and Scripture.

missing_figures.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under omissions/missing_figures:

No reference to Roman Catholic developments on revelation and Scripture, such as Vatican I or Vatican II’s Dei Verbum, which would provide a broader doctrinal context for evaluating Barth and Schleiermacher.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
missing_figures.answer_markdown:
The identified omission is that my essay treated Barth and Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation in isolation from major Roman Catholic magisterial developments (Vatican I and Vatican II’s *Dei Verbum*), thereby lacking a broader dogmatic horizon within which to situate and assess their proposals from a Reformed standpoint.

## Historical setting

Vatican I’s constitution *Dei Filius* (1870) and Vatican II’s *Dei Verbum* (1965) together articulate the modern Roman Catholic doctrine of revelation and Scripture.

- *Dei Filius* defends the possibility and necessity of supernatural revelation against rationalism, affirms that God can be known by reason from created things, and insists that revelation is given in propositions to be believed with divine faith.
- *Dei Verbum* restates and develops this: revelation is God’s self-communication in deeds and words, culminating in Christ; Scripture and Tradition together transmit this one revelation; the magisterium is its authentic interpreter; and Scripture is inspired, teaching “solidly, faithfully and without error that truth which God wanted put into sacred writings for the sake of our salvation.”

Chronologically and conceptually, Schleiermacher stands over against *Dei Filius*, and Barth over against both constitutions, even when they sometimes polemically converge against rationalism or liberalism.

## Doctrinal analysis

From a Reformed confessional standpoint (Westminster, Three Forms of Unity), several lines of comparison are important.

- **Source and content of revelation.**  
  - Roman Catholicism (Vatican II) understands revelation fundamentally as God’s self-disclosure in Christ, communicated in history, then normatively transmitted in Scripture and Tradition, under magisterial oversight.  
  - Schleiermacher relocates revelation into the structure of religious self-consciousness, with Christ as the archetype of God-consciousness and Scripture as the classic expression of the community’s piety.  
  - Barth insists that revelation is a free act of God in the event of Jesus Christ, to which Scripture bears witness.

  Reformed theology affirms revelation as God’s objective self-disclosure in redemptive history and its inscripturated form, but rejects Schleiermacher’s subjectivization and Barth’s witness-only formulation, while also rejecting the Roman Catholic dual-source or “one source in two modes” model that makes Tradition co-normative and revelation dependent on magisterial determination.

- **Scripture: inspiration and inerrancy.**  
  - *Dei Verbum* affirms divine inspiration and inerrancy, but in a carefully qualified way (“for the sake of our salvation”), and places the text within a broader interpretive structure governed by Tradition and the magisterium.  
  - Schleiermacher treats Scripture as the historically conditioned, norm-forming expression of the early community’s piety, not as direct divine speech.  
  - Barth refuses to identify the biblical text simply with God’s Word; it becomes God’s Word in the event of divine self-witness.

  Reformed confessions insist that Scripture is the very Word of God written, fully inspired and infallible in all it affirms, and that it is self-authenticating and self-interpreting in the Spirit, not normed by extra-biblical tradition or dependent on existential event for its status as Word.

- **Natural revelation and natural theology.**  
  - Vatican I explicitly upholds the knowability of God by natural reason from creation and condemns its denial; *Dei Verbum* presupposes this.  
  - Schleiermacher refuses metaphysical natural theology in favor of the immediacy of religious feeling, though he does not construct a robust doctrine of natural revelation in the classical sense.  
  - Barth notoriously rejects natural theology (the “Nein” to Brunner) and tends functionally to deny a positive, theologically usable natural revelation apart from Christ.

  Reformed theology sides formally with Vatican I in affirming genuine natural revelation and a limited natural theology (Romans 1, Psalm 19), but rejects both Rome’s elevation of philosophical theism into a quasi-independent locus and Barth’s near-elimination of natural revelation as a positive source of accountability and knowledge.

- **Ecclesial mediation and authority.**  
  - *Dei Verbum* binds revelation, Scripture, Tradition, and magisterium into a single complex: the Church’s teaching office has final interpretive authority.  
  - Schleiermacher effectively relocates authority to the consciousness of the Christian community.  
  - Barth returns authority to God’s sovereign self-witness in Christ, but in practice locates normativity in the Church’s hearing of the biblical witness.

  The Reformed position affirms the Church’s ministerial authority but not a magisterial one: the Church receives and serves Scripture, but Scripture alone is the supreme judge in all controversies of religion.

## Evaluation

Placing Barth and Schleiermacher against the background of Vatican I and *Dei Verbum* clarifies that:

- Schleiermacher represents a subjectivist reduction of revelation that both Roman Catholicism and Reformed theology reject, though for different reasons.
- Barth shares with Rome a strong Christocentrism and a rejection of rationalist natural theology, yet he refuses Rome’s objectivist-propositional and ecclesially mediated account of revelation and undermines the direct identity of Scripture with God’s Word that Reformed theology insists upon.
- The Reformed position stands equidistant from Roman Catholic magisterialism and Schleiermacherian subjectivism, while also disagreeing with Barth’s collapse of revelation into existential event.

In light of these broader developments, the Reformed confessional stance holds that God’s revelation is objectively given in creation and supremely in Christ, infallibly inscripturated in Scripture as the sole final norm, and ministerially interpreted by the Church, without the subjectivist reductions of Schleiermacher, the event-ontology of Barth, or the magisterial superstructure of Roman Catholic dogma.

missing_figures.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under omissions/missing_figures:

Lack of engagement with major Barth interpreters on revelation such as Hans Urs von Balthasar, Eberhard Jüngel, or George Hunsinger, which could correct oversimplifications.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
missing_figures.answer_markdown:
The issue is that the earlier answer treated “Barth on revelation” in a largely textbook, compressed way, without showing how some major interpreters of Barth—Balthasar, Jüngel, Hunsinger—have nuanced or corrected the common oversimplifications, especially the idea that Barth simply “denies natural revelation” or “collapses revelation into sheer subjectivist encounter,” and without assessing those refinements from a Reformed confessional standpoint.

## Clarifying Barth’s Doctrine of Revelation

At the center of Barth’s mature position (especially in Church Dogmatics I/1–II/1) is:

- **Revelation as triune event**: God’s self-revelation is God the Father as the Revealer, the Son as the Revealed, the Spirit as the Revealing. Revelation is the triune God’s self-identical act and being.
- **Christological concentration**: All revelation is in, with, and through Jesus Christ, the Word made flesh. There is no independent sphere of “revelation” outside this Christological scope.
- **Threefold form of the Word**: Jesus Christ (the Word incarnate), Holy Scripture (the written Word), and church proclamation (the preached Word) are distinct but ordered forms in which the one Word encounters us by the Spirit.

From a Reformed perspective, this rightly stresses divine initiative, the centrality of Christ, and the necessity of the Spirit. It also raises questions about the ontological status of Scripture as revelation and about the relation of creation and Christ.

## Balthasar on Barth: Aesthetic and Analogical Nuances

Hans Urs von Balthasar’s early work on Barth (especially “The Theology of Karl Barth”) insists that:

- **Barth is not a pure “dialectical” negativist**: For Balthasar, Barth moves toward a strongly positive Christological form: the incarnate Son is the concrete Gestalt of revelation, not only the negation of human religion.
- **Analogia fidei vs. analogia entis**: Balthasar defends the Thomist “analogy of being,” but he acknowledges that Barth’s analogia fidei is not mere fideism; it is an ordered, participatory relation: in Christ the creature is genuinely taken up into the life of God.
- **Christologically ordered creation**: Balthasar shows how, for Barth, creation is always already ordered to Christ; revelation is the unveiling of this Christic order, rather than the imposition of an arbitrary decree.

From a Reformed standpoint:

- Balthasar helpfully resists caricatures of Barth as simply “irrational” or “anti-metaphysical.”  
- Yet Reformed theology cannot follow Balthasar’s analogia entis or his Marian and ecclesiological developments; the basic Barthian insistence that we know God as he gives himself in Christ and Word-Spirit ministry remains closer to the Reformed confessions.

## Jüngel: Being, Event, and God’s Self-Communication

Eberhard Jüngel radicalizes and clarifies Barth’s insight that:

- **“God’s being is in becoming”**: God’s being is not changed by history, but God’s being is the living, self-communicating being that determines itself toward us in Jesus Christ. God’s being is not static but eventful.
- **Revelation and ontology**: For Jüngel, revelation is not an external appendage; God in Christ gives himself such that in revelation we truly know who God is in himself. The epistemic event corresponds to ontological truth.
- **Against the “positivism of revelation” caricature**: Jüngel argues that Barth’s “revelation” is not bare authoritarian fiat; it is the self-interpreting, self-explanatory act of God, internally coherent and intelligible in its own light.

From a Reformed angle:

- Jüngel supports the Barthian claim that revelation is not a detachable deposit of propositions but the triune God’s self-giving in Christ, which is correct as far as it goes.
- However, Reformed orthodoxy insists that this self-giving necessarily includes and secures a stable, covenantal form of revealed truth in inscripturated words, not merely an “event” of encounter; Jüngel can underplay this durable, canonical aspect.

## Hunsinger: Dogmatic Motifs and Natural Revelation

George Hunsinger’s work (for example, “How to Read Karl Barth”) helps correct two common misreadings directly relevant to revelation and natural knowledge:

- **Actualism properly understood**:  
    - Barth’s “actualism” means that God’s grace and revelation are living acts, not impersonal structures or habits.  
    - Hunsinger stresses that this does not dissolve doctrine or Scripture into existential processes; rather, the doctrines describe the grammar of God’s ongoing acts, especially in the risen Christ.
- **Objectivism of revelation**:  
    - Hunsinger highlights Barth’s “objectivist” strand: revelation has a concrete, given object—Jesus Christ in history, attested in Scripture.  
    - Thus Barth is not a subjectivist: the eventfulness of revelation is the encounter with a determinate, once-for-all history.
- **Nuancing the denial of natural theology**:  
    - Hunsinger shows that Barth’s “Nein” is directed at autonomous, non-Christological natural theology as a formal method.  
    - Barth can still affirm that creation truly witnesses to God, but this witness is rightly interpreted only within the light of Christ and Scripture. The problem is not that creation is mute, but that fallen reason is not its own norm for hearing.

Here Hunsinger moves Barth closer to a classic Reformed structure:

- Reformed theology affirms a real natural revelation (Ps 19; Rom 1) that leaves humanity without excuse but cannot save, and insists that special revelation in Christ and Scripture is necessary and sufficient for saving knowledge.
- Hunsinger’s reading allows one to say that Barth, at his best, does not deny that creation witnesses to God, but rejects the idea that we can construct valid theology from that witness independently of Christ and the Word.

## Reformed Evaluation and Appropriation

From within a classic Reformed confessional framework:

- **Positively appropriable themes**:
    - The triune, Christological centering of revelation.  
    - The insistence that revelation is God’s free, sovereign act, not a human religious achievement.  
    - The stress that Scripture is a divinely ordained witness that the Spirit uses to confront us with Christ in the present.
- **Critical reservations**:
    - Ontologically, Barth and many of his interpreters blur the classical Creator–creature distinction by speaking of “God’s being in becoming” without maintaining sufficient metaphysical clarity about divine immutability.  
    - Epistemologically, the reluctance to call Scripture itself, as God-breathed text, “revelation” stands in tension with the Reformed doctrine of verbal inspiration and the clarity, sufficiency, and authority of Scripture as the inscripturated Word of God.  
    - Naturae theologiae: Barth’s polemic, even as nuanced by Hunsinger, tends to restrict legitimate talk of natural revelation more narrowly than the Reformed confessions, which affirm a real, though non-salvific, revelation of God in creation and providence.

Barth’s interpreters thus show that his doctrine of revelation is more nuanced, christologically and ontologically thick, and less simply “anti-natural-revelation” than is often claimed, but a classic Reformed position still must distinguish true natural revelation from illegitimate natural theology and insist that God’s saving self-revelation is normatively given and preserved in the verbally inspired Scriptures.

From a Reformed angle:

  • Jüngel supports the Barthian claim that revelation is not a detachable deposit of propositions but the triune God’s self-giving in Christ, which is correct as far as it goes.
  • However, Reformed orthodoxy insists that this self-giving necessarily includes and secures a stable, covenantal form of revealed truth in inscripturated words, not merely an “event” of encounter; Jüngel can underplay this durable, canonical aspect.

Hunsinger: Dogmatic Motifs and Natural Revelation

George Hunsinger’s work (for example, “How to Read Karl Barth”) helps correct two common misreadings directly relevant to revelation and natural knowledge:

  • Actualism properly understood:
    • Barth’s “actualism” means that God’s grace and revelation are living acts, not impersonal structures or habits.
    • Hunsinger stresses that this does not dissolve doctrine or Scripture into existential processes; rather, the doctrines describe the grammar of God’s ongoing acts, especially in the risen Christ.
  • Objectivism of revelation:
    • Hunsinger highlights Barth’s “objectivist” strand: revelation has a concrete, given object—Jesus Christ in history, attested in Scripture.
    • Thus Barth is not a subjectivist: the eventfulness of revelation is the encounter with a determinate, once-for-all history.
  • Nuancing the denial of natural theology:
    • Hunsinger shows that Barth’s “Nein” is directed at autonomous, non-Christological natural theology as a formal method.
    • Barth can still affirm that creation truly witnesses to God, but this witness is rightly interpreted only within the light of Christ and Scripture. The problem is not that creation is mute, but that fallen reason is not its own norm for hearing.

Here Hunsinger moves Barth closer to a classic Reformed structure:

  • Reformed theology affirms a real natural revelation (Ps 19; Rom 1) that leaves humanity without excuse but cannot save, and insists that special revelation in Christ and Scripture is necessary and sufficient for saving knowledge.
  • Hunsinger’s reading allows one to say that Barth, at his best, does not deny that creation witnesses to God, but rejects the idea that we can construct valid theology from that witness independently of Christ and the Word.

Reformed Evaluation and Appropriation

From within a classic Reformed confessional framework:

  • Positively appropriable themes:
    • The triune, Christological centering of revelation.
    • The insistence that revelation is God’s free, sovereign act, not a human religious achievement.
    • The stress that Scripture is a divinely ordained witness that the Spirit uses to confront us with Christ in the present.
  • Critical reservations:
    • Ontologically, Barth and many of his interpreters blur the classical Creator–creature distinction by speaking of “God’s being in becoming” without maintaining sufficient metaphysical clarity about divine immutability.
    • Epistemologically, the reluctance to call Scripture itself, as God-breathed text, “revelation” stands in tension with the Reformed doctrine of verbal inspiration and the clarity, sufficiency, and authority of Scripture as the inscripturated Word of God.
    • Naturae theologiae: Barth’s polemic, even as nuanced by Hunsinger, tends to restrict legitimate talk of natural revelation more narrowly than the Reformed confessions, which affirm a real, though non-salvific, revelation of God in creation and providence.

Barth’s interpreters thus show that his doctrine of revelation is more nuanced, christologically and ontologically thick, and less simply “anti-natural-revelation” than is often claimed, but a classic Reformed position still must distinguish true natural revelation from illegitimate natural theology and insist that God’s saving self-revelation is normatively given and preserved in the verbally inspired Scriptures.

missing_figures.answer_markdown:
The omission concerns the lack of engagement with significant Protestant orthodox and confessional Lutheran critics of Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation, whose objections expose more sharply why his account is structurally incompatible with classic confessional Christianity.

## Doctrinal location of the critique

From a Reformed confessional standpoint (and in parallel, confessional Lutheran), Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation is problematic at several key points:

- It relocates **revelation’s locus** from God’s objective speaking and acting in history to the structure of Christian self-consciousness.
- It redefines **the essence of religion** as Gefühl (the feeling of absolute dependence) rather than knowledge of God grounded in God’s own propositional self-disclosure.
- It treats **Scripture** not as the inspired, inerrant Word of God but as the historically conditioned, yet normative, expression of the church’s piety.

Orthodox critics focus on how these moves dissolve the formal principle of the Reformation (sola Scriptura) and undermine the material principle (solus Christus as the once-for-all, finished revelation and redemption).

## Protestant orthodox and Reformed criticism

Within a classic Reformed frame, the main lines of criticism would be:

- **Revelation as divine self-disclosure, not religious consciousness.**  
  Reformed orthodoxy insists that revelation is first God’s objective act: God speaks in creation, covenant, prophecy, incarnation, and inspired Scripture. Human religious consciousness is the *reception* of this disclosure, not its essence. Schleiermacher inverts this relation, making revelation a function of piety rather than of God’s lordly speech.

- **The cognitive content of revelation.**  
  Traditional Protestant theology holds that revelation necessarily has **doctrinal content**: God reveals who he is, his will, promises, and threats. Schleiermacher relegates doctrine to a second-order expression of feeling, derivative and revisable. Orthodox critics argue this empties “revelation” of truth-claims about God and turns theology into a descriptive psychology or phenomenology of Christian experience.

- **The status of Scripture.**  
  Reformed standards (and the Lutheran symbols) treat Scripture as *God’s own Word written*, fully inspired and therefore trustworthy in what it teaches. Schleiermacher’s view of Scripture as the classic expression of communal God-consciousness:
  
    - makes its normativity functional rather than ontological (Scripture norms because of its historical role, not because of its divine authorship);
    - makes its authority relative to its power to sustain piety, thereby subjecting Scripture to an external criterion (the religious feeling it ought to produce).

  Orthodox critics therefore see Schleiermacher as displacing the principium cognoscendi externum (Scripture) with an internal principle (Gefühl), a move that is formally anti-confessional.

- **Christ and revelation.**  
  Classic Protestantism affirms that Christ is the final revelation of God precisely as the incarnate, crucified, and risen Son whose work is once-for-all and historically completed; Scripture then interprets and testifies this event. Schleiermacher locates Christ’s revelatory significance primarily in his perfect God-consciousness that is communicated to the community. Critics argue:
  
    - this psychologizes Christ’s mediatorship,  
    - minimizes the forensic and historical dimensions of atonement,  
    - and makes “revelation in Christ” effectively indistinguishable from the ongoing religious life of the community that participates in his consciousness.

  That is, Christ becomes the archetype and source of a specific religious experience rather than the unique, definitive Word-event by which God speaks and saves.

- **Natural and special revelation.**  
  Reformed confessionalism affirms both general revelation (in creation and providence) and special revelation (culminating in Christ and Scripture). Schleiermacher’s suspicion of metaphysics and relegation of nature to a mere occasion for religious feeling leads to a flattening in which:
  
    - “revelation” no longer grounds true knowledge of God from creation,  
    - and “special revelation” no longer functions as a new cognitive disclosure but as a heightened form of the universal religious a priori.

  Critics argue that this effectively abolishes the Reformed distinction and with it the proper basis for law, gospel, and covenant history.

## Confessional Lutheran contributions

Confessional Lutheran critics raise parallel concerns but often sharpen them at two loci:

- **The external Word (Verbum externum).**  
  Lutheran theology insists that God binds himself to the external Word and sacraments; faith clings to an *extra nos* gospel promise. Schleiermacher, by centering inner piety, undermines this externality:
  
    - the preached Word becomes an instrument for evoking or deepening feeling rather than the concrete divine address that creates faith;  
    - the sacraments are evaluated by their religious “effect,” not by Christ’s objective institution and promise.

  This is seen as a fundamental betrayal of the Reformation’s insistence that assurance rests on God’s speaking outside us, not on our consciousness.

- **Justification and objectivity of grace.**  
  Lutheran dogmatics locates justification in God’s forensic declaration on the basis of Christ’s work. Schleiermacher’s account, in which “justification and reconciliation” describe transformations in God-consciousness, appears to critics as a re-interpretation of justification as a mode of religious life rather than a once-for-all verdict. This is not merely a soteriological deviation; it confirms the revision of revelation into immanent religious experience.

## Reformed evaluative judgment

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation is judged deficient because it shifts the center of gravity:

- from God’s sovereign, verbal self-disclosure in history to human self-consciousness;
- from Scripture as principial, God-breathed norm to Scripture as paradigmatic but revisable witness to communal piety;
- from Christ’s finished, once-for-all revelatory and redemptive work to the ongoing communication of his religious consciousness to the community.

Consequently, the confessional Reformed and Lutheran critiques converge in holding that Schleiermacher’s notion of revelation substitutes the structure of Christian feeling for the Word of the living God, thereby relinquishing the Reformation’s foundational doctrine of Scripture and of Christ as God’s definitive self-revelation.

## Restatement of the issue

The criticism is that the comparison of Schleiermacher and Barth on revelation relied mainly on secondary characterizations and on the early Speeches, without engaging Schleiermacher’s mature and systematic account in The Christian Faith (Der christliche Glaube), where his doctrines of revelation, God-consciousness, and Scripture receive their definitive formulation. A proper answer must show familiarity with those loci in The Christian Faith and then evaluate them from a Reformed perspective.

## Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation in The Christian Faith

### God-consciousness and revelation

In The Christian Faith, Schleiermacher defines the essence of religion not as doctrine, ethics, or metaphysics, but as **Gefühl**, specifically the **feeling of absolute dependence**. This “God-consciousness” is:

- An immediate, pre-reflective self-awareness of our being-determined by God.
- Inseparable from creaturely self-consciousness; as I recognize my finitude, I experience myself as absolutely dependent on the Whence of my existence.

Revelation, in this framework, is not primarily a set of divine propositions or external acts, but the **historical emergence and intensification of God-consciousness within the corporate life of the church**. God “reveals” himself as human consciousness is brought into a certain pious state, whose highest and normative form is found in Christ.

Thus:

- Revelation is fundamentally **immanent**: it unfolds within the structures of human consciousness and history.
- “Supernatural” describes the **origin** of God-consciousness (God as Whence), not a series of discrete miraculous intrusions that deliver doctrinal content.

From a Reformed standpoint this radically shifts the center of gravity: revelation becomes an event in human subjectivity rather than an objective self-disclosing address of the triune God in word and deed.

### Christ and the communication of God-consciousness

In The Christian Faith Schleiermacher speaks of Christ as possessing a **perfect, constant God-consciousness** that is “vermittelnd” (mediating):

- Christ’s uniqueness lies in the absolute potency and unbroken continuity of his God-consciousness.
- Redemption consists in the **communication of this God-consciousness** to the believing community, so that believers participate in the same filial consciousness.

Revelation, therefore:

- Is “Christological” only in the sense that Christ is the **origin and exemplar** of the highest form of religious self-consciousness.
- Is not, in Reformed terms, a once-for-all divine self-disclosure in the incarnation, cross, and resurrection understood as redemptive-historical acts with determinate cognitive content, but the **ongoing diffusion** of Christ’s consciousness.

This Christology is functional and anthropological rather than ontological and trinitarian in the classic sense, and it relocates revelation from God’s external works and speech to an interiorized, communicable consciousness.

### Scripture as witness and norm in The Christian Faith

In The Christian Faith Schleiermacher’s doctrine of Scripture is tightly correlated to this structure.

- Scripture is the **record of the piety** (God-consciousness) of the primitive Christian community, in which Christ’s God-consciousness was first fully and paradigmatically mediated.
- Its authority is **ecclesial and historical**: it is the original and normative expression of Christian piety, not the inerrant inscription of divine speech.

Accordingly:

- Inspiration is not a supernatural verbal process, but the fact that the authors’ piety was closely and originally related to Christ and to the earliest community.
- Scripture’s normativity is **functional and relative**: it is the standard insofar as it best expresses the original and purest form of Christian God-consciousness; yet piety must always be re-expressed in new historical forms.
- Doctrines are second-order **descriptive accounts** of this piety, not revealed truths that bind the church because God has spoken them.

Here Schleiermacher’s mature position in The Christian Faith confirms and systematizes what is only adumbrated in the Speeches: revelation is not Scripture itself, but the religious experience that Scripture witnesses to; Scripture is a privileged but historically conditioned index of that experience.

## Reformed evaluation

From a classic Reformed confessional standpoint, The Christian Faith presents three fundamental reversals.

### Objectivity and externality of revelation

Reformed theology:

- Confesses a **verbal, propositional, and historical** revelation: God reveals himself in mighty acts (creation, covenant, incarnation, cross, resurrection) interpreted by divinely given words, culminating in Christ and inscripturated in Scripture.
- Maintains that revelation is grounded in God’s **free, sovereign address** from outside us (extra nos) and then internalized by the Spirit.

Schleiermacher, by contrast, internalizes revelation as **God-consciousness** and makes the external historical phenomena (including Christ’s acts and Scripture) significant only as occasions and expressions of this inner piety. This undermines the asymmetry between God’s speaking subjectivity and human receptive passivity that Reformed theology regards as essential.

### Christology and the nature of self-disclosure

Reformed Christology:

- Affirms the eternal Son as **true God and true man**, personally united, whose historical life, death, and resurrection are themselves revelatory acts of the triune God.
- Treats Christ not merely as the highest instance of God-consciousness, but as **God himself speaking and acting in history**.

Schleiermacher’s Christ in The Christian Faith is soteriologically central but ontologically thinned: his uniqueness lies in consciousness, not in the hypostatic union as a metaphysical reality revealed in Scripture. Consequently, revelation becomes the **spread of a consciousness-pattern**, not the manifestation of the incarnate Word’s once-for-all saving work interpreted by inspired apostolic testimony.

### Scripture and doctrinal authority

Reformed confessions hold:

- Scripture is **the Word of God written**, inspired by the Spirit so that its words are God’s words, inerrant in all that they affirm, and the **final norm** for faith and life.
- Revelation is not merely what the community experiences, but what God has objectively made known and fixed in the canon.

Schleiermacher’s doctrine in The Christian Faith displaces this:

- Authority shifts from Scripture as God’s speech to **ecclesial piety** as the living locus of God-consciousness.
- Doctrinal development is driven not by exegesis of an inerrant text, but by the evolving **self-interpretation of the church’s piety** in changing historical situations.

This renders Scripture’s authority derivative and revisable and makes dogmatics a phenomenology of piety rather than an exposition of revealed truth.

## Conclusion

Direct engagement with The Christian Faith shows that Schleiermacher systematically redefines revelation as the historical intensification of God-consciousness in Christ and the church, with Scripture functioning as the first and normative, yet historically conditioned, expression of that piety, a reconfiguration that stands in principled tension with the Reformed confession of God’s objective, once-for-all, verbally inscripturated self-revelation in Christ and Scripture.

The issue is that Schleiermacher’s doctrine of revelation was described largely in systematic shorthand (feeling of absolute dependence, communal piety, etc.) without actually grounding the account in the argument and idiom of the Speeches to its Cultured Despisers, especially where he explicitly redefines “revelation” and “God-consciousness” for his Romantic audience.

## Historical and Literary Setting of the Speeches

Schleiermacher’s Speeches (1799) are occasional pieces addressing Berlin intellectuals tempted to abandon Christianity for Enlightenment rationalism or Romantic aesthetics. He aims to rehabilitate “religion” as a sui generis domain, distinct from:

- Metaphysics (knowledge, concepts, proofs of God).
- Morality (ethics, virtue, Kantian autonomy).

This context controls his account of revelation: revelation must be construed so that it is neither a set of rationally demonstrable propositions nor a code of moral prescriptions, but the inner essence of “religion” as he redefines it.

## Schleiermacher’s Religious A Priori and Revelation in the Speeches

In the early Speeches, Schleiermacher does not yet use the later dogmatic formula “feeling of absolute dependence,” but the conceptual structure is already present.

### Religion as Intuition and Feeling

In the Second Speech (“On the Nature of Religion”) he argues that:

- Religion is fundamentally **Anschauung** (intuition) and **Gefühl** (feeling), an immediate consciousness of the infinite in and through the finite, not discursive knowledge or moral willing.

Revelation in this frame is:

- Not God’s self-disclosure through propositional communication, but the **immediate givenness of the Infinite** in the finite to consciousness.
- Essentially **coextensive with the emergence of genuine religious intuition**; where religion in this sense is, “revelation” has taken place.

In the Fourth and Fifth Speeches, Schleiermacher treats Christianity and the Church:

- Christ is presented less as a metaphysical God-man defined by natures and more as the one in whom **God-consciousness is archetypal and transparent**.
- The Church is the historical community in which this consciousness is **communicated and intensified** through mutual speech, worship, and example.

- **Revelation is historicized and communalized.** The Christian community is the ongoing historical form in which the original religious intuition focused in Christ is “expressed” and transmitted.
- Scripture, while not yet fully theorized as in the later Glaubenslehre, functions implicitly as a **classical expression of earlier Christian God-consciousness**, not as a materially inerrant, once-for-all deposit.

Schleiermacher attacks conceptions of revelation that emphasize:

- Isolated supernatural interventions or miracles as “proofs.”
- Externally imposed doctrines to be believed on authority.

For him:

missing_primary_texts.answer_markdown:
The concern is that my essay treated Barth’s doctrine of revelation largely through Römerbrief and the Brunner debate, without engaging the programmatic account in Church Dogmatics I/1 (on the Word of God) and II/1 (on the knowledge of God), which are decisive both for understanding Barth himself and for a Reformed evaluation.

## Barth’s doctrine of the Word of God in Church Dogmatics I/1

In CD I/1 Barth defines revelation in explicitly trinitarian and christological terms: God’s revelation is God himself in his free self-unveiling. This is not an object alongside God but an event in which God is simultaneously Revealer, Revelation, and Revealedness.

Within that framework he develops the famous threefold form of the Word of God:

- **First, Jesus Christ as the Word incarnate.** Christ alone is properly revelation; all else is subordinate form and witness.
- **Second, Holy Scripture as the written Word.** Scripture is the normative, unique, and indispensable witness to God’s revelation in Christ. It is not identified univocally with revelation, but Barth speaks of it as the Word of God “in virtue of” God’s free decision to use it.
- **Third, the preaching of the church as the proclaimed Word.** In the event of preaching, God may make the human word a vehicle of his own self-witness.

From a Reformed confessional standpoint, CD I/1 is both closer to and yet decisively divergent from classical Reformed doctrine. There is welcome emphasis on:

- The primacy of Christ as the center and content of revelation.
- The trinitarian character of revelation as a free act of God.
- The instrumental role of Scripture and preaching in God’s self-disclosure.

However, Barth’s refusal to speak of Scripture as revelation in a stable, ontological sense—his reluctance to say that the inscripturated text as such is the Word of God—conflicts with the Reformed identification of Scripture with God’s written Word (Westminster Confession of Faith, Belgic Confession). For the Reformed, the “event” of God’s speaking in preaching presupposes the prior, fixed identity of the canonical text as God-breathed revelation.

## Barth on the knowledge of God in Church Dogmatics II/1

CD II/1 systematically works out the doctrine of the knowledge of God, again decisively christological. Several features are crucial:

- **Knowledge of God grounded in election in Christ.** God is known only as he elects to be “for us” in Jesus Christ; there is no independent point of contact in human nature.
- **Rejection of natural theology.** Barth argues that there is no valid knowledge of God apart from his self-revelation in Christ; any appeal to an autonomous natural knowledge is ruled out.
- **Analogy of faith versus analogia entis.** Against Roman Catholic and much Protestant natural theology, Barth rejects an ontological analogy of being and insists on an “analogy of faith,” where all true knowledge of God is determined by God’s self-speaking in the gospel.

From a Reformed standpoint, II/1 again shows convergence and divergence:

- **Convergence**:
    - Knowledge of God is covenantal, grounded in God’s gracious self-initiative.
    - Fallen humanity cannot, by autonomous reason, achieve saving or reliable theological knowledge.
    - The priority of special revelation over philosophical or speculative theism.

- **Divergence**:
    - Classic Reformed confessions affirm a true, though non-saving, natural revelation of God in creation and conscience that renders humanity without excuse. Barth’s near-total denial of a valid natural knowledge of God goes beyond Reformed strictures on fallen reason and collapses general revelation into special revelation in Christ.
    - The radicalization of the christological focus leads to a kind of methodological exclusivism: all theology must be directly and explicitly Christocentric, which can obscure the distinct yet harmonious testimony of general and special revelation affirmed by the Reformed tradition.

## Filling the omission

A properly grounded comparison of Barth and Schleiermacher on revelation must therefore place CD I/1 and II/1 at the center:

- Barth’s mature view is not simply an early dialectical protest (Römerbrief) or a polemical NEIN to Brunner, but a developed trinitarian–christological account in which:
    - Revelation is God’s triune self-communication in Christ.
    - Scripture and preaching are genuinely the Word of God, yet only as divinely used witnesses.
    - Natural theology is rejected in principle, not only in practice.

A Reformed evaluation must affirm Barth’s insistence on the primacy of God’s sovereign self-revelation in Christ, while rejecting his event-centered, non-identical account of Scripture as the Word of God and his virtual exclusion of natural revelation as confessed in the Reformed symbols.

missing_primary_texts.answer_markdown:
The concern is that my written comparison of Barth and Schleiermacher on revelation relied almost entirely on Barth’s early crisis theology (especially the first and second Römerbrief and the Brunner exchange), without drawing on the Göttingen and Münster dogmatics lectures, where Barth’s doctrine of revelation clearly develops and stabilizes; so the account of Barth was historically and theologically one-sided.

## Historical setting and trajectory

After the second edition of Romans (1922), Barth moves into teaching dogmatics at Göttingen (1921–1925) and then Münster (1925–1930). These lecture cycles are crucial because:

- They begin the shift from purely dialectical “crisis” preaching to a more classically dogmatic, ecclesially ordered account of revelation.
- They prefigure and partially anticipate the structure and content of Church Dogmatics I/1 and I/2.
- They show Barth wrestling more systematically with Scripture, the church, and dogmatic tradition, rather than focusing almost exclusively on the sheer “otherness” of God.

Thus, to understand Barth on revelation one must not stop at the epistolary rhetoric of Römerbrief but follow how, in these lectures, he deepens and reconfigures his position.

## Doctrinal analysis: Revelation in the Göttingen and Münster dogmatics

In these lectures, several key developments appear.

- **From pure crisis to positive dogmatics.**  
  Barth continues to insist that revelation is God’s sovereign self-speaking, not a religious a priori in man; yet he begins to treat this revelation in ordered loci, with prolegomena, doctrine of the Word, and trinitarian grounding. Revelation is no longer merely the “No” to religion and culture but the determinate act in which God the Trinity addresses the church.

- **Intensified Christocentrism and the threefold Word.**  
  The basic pattern that will become canonical in Church Dogmatics is already apparent:
  
    - Jesus Christ as the one Word of God and center of revelation.
    - Holy Scripture as the prophetic-apostolic witness to this once-for-all revelation.
    - Church proclamation as derivative and dependent speech that has authority only as it is bound to Scripture and used by the Spirit.
  
  Revelation remains event-character, but the event is now steadily tethered to this structured threefold form rather than left in purely paradoxical terms.

- **Scripture’s place: witness, instrument, and authority.**  
  Barth is still careful to say that Scripture is not revelation in itself, but the ordained means through which God speaks. In Göttingen and Münster, however, he:
  
    - Leans more heavily into the concreteness and givenness of the canonical text.
    - Speaks in ways that sound very close to a functional inerrancy at the level of divine use: Scripture does not fail to serve God’s revelatory purpose.
    - Binds proclamation tightly to Scripture, fencing against any appeal to inner religious experience or culture as a co-ordinate norm.
  
  While he does not adopt the Reformed orthodox identity of Scripture and revelation, the distance from that position is narrowed in practice: the church has no access to revelation except as it hears Christ in and through these writings.

- **Church and tradition.**  
  The early Römerbrief posture is suspicious of all “religion.” In Göttingen and Münster, Barth gives a more positive account of the church as the community called into being by God’s Word. He critically retrieves elements of Reformed confessional theology and patristic/medieval exegesis under the rule of Scripture. Revelation retains its divine freedom, but it is not an unchurched event; it is ordered to and normally given within the life of the church as hearing and preaching Scripture.

- **Revelation and natural theology.**  
  Barth’s Göttingen dogmatics already exhibits his opposition to natural theology, but the later violent “Nein” to Brunner is not yet fully formed. Instead, Barth’s emphasis is:
  
    - Any true knowledge of God is grounded in God’s self-speaking in Christ and Scripture.
    - Philosophy, history, and nature can be “parables” or “indirect lights,” but they do not constitute a separate, autonomous revelatory source.
  
  This anticipates the stronger later rejection, but in Göttingen/Münster the language leaves somewhat more room for acknowledging creational order and a kind of pre-understanding, though always subordinated to Christ.

## Evaluation from a Reformed confessional standpoint

From a classic Reformed perspective, the Göttingen and Münster materials exhibit both convergence and abiding divergence.

- **Points of convergence.**
  
    - The rejection of Schleiermacher’s grounding of revelation in religious Gefühl and communal consciousness aligns with the Reformed insistence on revelation as God’s free, objective, verbal self-disclosure.
    - The centering of revelation in the incarnate, crucified, and risen Christ corresponds closely to the Reformed Christological concentration of Scripture’s message.
    - The strong tethering of proclamation to Scripture as the unique prophetic-apostolic norm echoes the Reformed sola Scriptura principle and the notion of ministerial, not magisterial, church authority.

- **Points of divergence.**
  
    - Barth still refuses to identify the inscripturated Word and the revelatory act at the ontological level; Reformed orthodoxy maintains that the written Word is itself God’s speech, not merely the site where God may speak again.
    - His near-elimination of independent general revelation and natural knowledge of God conflicts with the confessional affirmation that creation and conscience truly and objectively reveal God, though not savingly.
    - The heavily actualistic account of revelation (revelation as event that “happens”) leaves less room for the stable, covenantal character of the inscripturated Word as a standing form of revelation, even when it is not being subjectively appropriated.

Still, the Göttingen and Münster lectures demonstrate that Barth is not merely an anti-metaphysical dialectician but a theologian moving into a more classically dogmatic, Scripture-governed account of revelation, one that critiques Schleiermacher’s subjectivism while still falling short of the Reformed confession of Scripture as the perspicuous, sufficient, and inherently revelatory Word of God.

missing_primary_texts.answer_markdown:
The concern is that the earlier treatment of Barth and Brunner on natural revelation reduced their exchange to the famous “NEIN!” and thus failed to engage the arguments of Brunner’s *Natur und Gnade* and Barth’s *Nein!* in a way that shows what, precisely, they were disagreeing about and what is at stake theologically.

## Historical and Textual Clarification

Brunner’s *Natur und Gnade* (1934) tries to retrieve a chastened natural theology within a broadly dialectical framework. His basic claims include:

- **The imago Dei and the “formal” capacity.** Brunner argues that although the material content of the image of God is ruined by sin, there remains a “formal” side: humanity retains a capacity for address by God, a structural openness. This is his *Anknüpfungspunkt* (point of contact).

- **General revelation and conscience.** He maintains that God reveals himself in creation and in human conscience such that there is a genuine, though suppressed, knowledge of God among fallen humans. This knowledge is not saving and not sufficient for the gospel, but it is real knowledge of God as Creator and Judge.

- **Grace presupposing nature.** Brunner appeals, in a modified way, to the traditional dictum that grace does not destroy but perfects nature. For him, special revelation in Christ presupposes the creational structures in which that revelation is received.

- **Sharp subordination to Christ.** Brunner insists that natural revelation is radically clarified and judged by Christ, yet he refuses to say that it is nullified. There remains, he claims, an inescapable natural knowledge of God that grounds human responsibility.

Barth’s *Nein!* is not a mere emotive rejection but a detailed rebuttal on several fronts:

- **Total corruption of natural knowledge.** Barth holds that fallen humanity has no positive, trustworthy knowledge of God apart from God’s self-revelation in Christ. Any supposed “knowledge of God” in nature or conscience is, in practice, an idol constructed in sin.

- **The point of contact as an act of grace, not a structure.** Barth relocates the *Anknüpfungspunkt* entirely into the sovereign act of God in revelation. The “capacity” for revelation is not a residual structure in humanity but is created anew when God addresses a person in Christ through the Spirit.

- **Dogmatic concern: no independent sphere.** Barth fears that admitting a genuine natural knowledge of God yields an autonomous realm—nature, reason, culture—where humans can speak of God apart from Christ. - **Polemic against “orders of creation.”** In the background is Barth’s opposition to certain Lutheran and Reformed appeals to creation orders as a basis for political and ethical claims, which he saw as vulnerable to nationalist and ideological co-option (as in the 1930s German context).

## Doctrinal Analysis from a Reformed Confessional Standpoint

Classic Reformed confessional theology sides partly with Brunner and partly with Barth, but on principled grounds distinct from both.

From the confessions:

- **Affirmation of general revelation.** Psalm 19 and Romans 1–2 ground the confessional teaching (Westminster Confession of Faith 1.1, 21.1; Belgic Confession 2) that God makes himself known in the works of creation and providence. This revelation is:

    - Truly revelatory of God’s eternal power, wisdom, and goodness.
    - Universally accessible.
    - Sufficient to leave humanity “without excuse,” though not to grant saving knowledge of Christ.

- **Reality yet perversity of natural knowledge.** The confessions imply that fallen humans genuinely “know” God in a sense (they suppress the truth they have), so there is a real cognitive relation—but this knowledge is not morally or religiously right. It is always twisted into idolatry and self-justification apart from regenerating grace.

Viewed in that light:

- **Agreement with Brunner.** Reformed theology concurs that:

    - There is a structural side to the image of God that persists after the fall (rationality, conscience, relational capacity).
    - Creation and conscience bear witness to God and ground human responsibility.
    - Special revelation does not annihilate creaturely structures but restores and rightly orders them.

- **Critique of Brunner.** Yet from a confessional standpoint:

    - Brunner’s *Anknüpfungspunkt* language tends to over-positive a fallen capacity, speaking as though there is a quasi-neutral platform in man on which grace simply “builds.”
    - He risks blurring the Reformed distinction between a real, objective revelation in nature and the subjective, noetic corruption that renders fallen man incapable of using that revelation aright.

- **Qualified agreement with Barth.** The Reformed tradition resonates with Barth’s emphasis that:

    - Saving knowledge of God is exclusively in Christ and by the Spirit.
    - Fallen humanity cannot, by unaided reason, attain a true theology, even if they cannot escape God’s revelation.

- **Critique of Barth.** Barth, however, tends to:

    - Collapse the distinction between revelation and its reception, so that the noetic corruption of the sinner appears to erase the reality of general revelation itself.
    - Undercut the confessional insistence that creation and providence are a genuine divine self-disclosure, even though always misused in sin and needing Scripture and regeneration for right interpretation.

A confessional Reformed correction would therefore say: Brunner is right that there is God-given, creational structure and general revelation grounding human accountability, and Barth is right that fallen man turns this inevitably into idolatry without Christ, but the objective fact of natural revelation and the residual image must not be denied in the name of protecting the primacy of special revelation.

The Reformed position thus maintains both that God truly reveals himself in nature and conscience and that only the regenerating work of the Spirit through Scripture and Christ enables this revelation to be rightly known and confessed.
